questions.question: How can you try to prevent seizures in a woman with severe preeclampsia?
questions.description:
To prevent seizures in a woman with severe preeclampsia, you can try the following:

Magnesium Sulphate.

Terminate pregnancy.

answers.value: Let her rest in a silent and dark room

questions.question: Why must you never give IV fluids faster than 1 L in 12 hours to a preeclamptic woman?
questions.description: You must never give IV fluids faster than 1 L in 12 hours to a preeclamptic woman, because she can die from pulmonary oedema.

answers.value: It reduces the effect of Magnesium Sulphate
She can die from pulmonary oedema

questions.question: In case of severe pre-eclampsia and eclampsia, what should be measured every half hour?
questions.description:
In case of severe pre-eclampsia and eclampsia, the following should be measured every half hour:

Respiratory rate and blood pressure.

Tendon reflexes.

Foetal heart rate.

questions.question: What is the correct first dose of Magnesium Sulphate?
questions.description: The correct first dose of Magnesium Sulphate is 4 grams IV.

questions.question: Magnesium Sulphate can cause heart arrest. True or false?
questions.description: True, Magnesium Sulphate can cause heart arrest.

questions.question: What are signs of intoxication with Magnesium Sulphate?
questions.description:
Signs of intoxication with Magnesium Sulphate are:

Loss of tendon reflexes.

Respiratory depression and/or heart arrest.

questions.question: When should you NOT give second dose of Magnesium Sulphate?
questions.description:
You should NOT give a second dose of Magnesium Sulphate when:

Loss of tendon reflexes or heart arrest.

If you do not have Calcium Gluconate.

RR<16.

answers.value: Loss of tendon reflexes or heart arrest
If you do not have Calcium Gluconate

questions.question: In case of eclampsia at peripheral level, what would you do?
questions.description: In case of eclampsia at peripheral level, you stabilise the woman and refer.

answers.value: Refer immediately and stabilise at higher level facility

questions.question: How would you manage eclamptic fits between gestational weeks 28-34?
questions.description:
You manage eclamptic fits between gestational weeks 28-34 in the following way:

Steroids for foetal lung maturation.

Control BP.

Give Magnesium Sulphate.

questions.question: Why should you actively manage the third stage of labour?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/active_management
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/intro
questions.description: You should actively manage the third stage of labour to reduce the risk of postpartum haemorrhage.

answers.value: To reduce the risk of postpartum haemorrhage
To reduce the risk of postpartum infections
To reduce the risk of postpartum seizures

questions.question: Which medicine should you prepare before every birth?
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/give_a_uterotonic_drug
questions.description: You prepare Oxytocin before every birth.

questions.question: Why should you give Oxytocin?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/oxytocin
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/give_a_uterotonic_drug
questions.description: You give Oxytocin to stimulate the uterus to contract.

answers.value: To stop the pulsation in the umbilical cord
To stimulate the uterus to contract

questions.question: How much Oxytocin IM should you give to the mother after birth?
questions.description: You should give 10 IU Oxytocin IM to the mother after birth.

questions.question: When should Oxytocin be given?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/oxytocin
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/give_a_uterotonic_drug
questions.description: Oxytocin should be given within one minute after birth of the newborn.

answers.value: Seconds before the foetus is born
Within one minute after birth of the newborn
Right after delivery of the placenta

questions.question: How should Oxytocin preferably be stored?
questions.description:
Oxytocin should preferably be stored:

Between 2 and 8 degrees Celsius.

answers.value: In a dark room at room temperature between 25-30 degrees Celsius

questions.question: What to do if you do not have Oxytocin?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/no_oxytocin
questions.description: If you do not have Oxytocin, give 600 micrograms of Misoprostol.

answers.value: Since this is a preventive drug administration, no alternative is necessary

questions.question: How can heat-stable carbetocin be administered to prevent PPH?
questions.description: Give 100 mcg IM/IV  Heat-stable Carbetocin as soon as possible after delivery.

questions.question: When should you assess the newborn after birth?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/newborn_on_the_mother
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/assess_the_newborn
questions.description: You should assess the newborn immediately after birth.

answers.value: After the newborn has tried to breastfeed
It is only necessary to assess the newborn if it does not cry after birth

questions.question: A baby is born in thick meconium and is in need of resuscitation. Should you dry before suction?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/green_newborn
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/assess_the_newborn
questions.description: Yes, you should dry before performing suction if a baby is born in thick meconium and is in need of resuscitation.

questions.question: How should you clear the newborn’s airway when it is born with thick meconium and you have to ventilate?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/green_newborn
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/assess_the_newborn
questions.description: You clear the newborn's airway when it is born and you have to ventilate with thick meconium by suctioning the meconium out of the mouth and nose.

answers.value: By suctioning the meconium out of the mouth and nose
By blowing in the baby’s mouth and nose
By drying the meconium away from the baby’s mouth and nose
Wait and see if the newborn can clear the airways itself by screaming – if not suction.

questions.question: What should you do with the newborn immediatley after birth?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/brand_new_baby
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/assess_the_newborn
questions.description: Newborns have difficulties regulating their temperature and lose body heat quickly. Therefore, dry the newborn immediately with a dry towel and assess.

answers.value: Clamp and cut the umbilical cord
Place the newborn on the weighing scale
Dry the baby with a dry towel and assess
Dry the baby with a wet, hot towel and put it at the mother’s breast

questions.question: How should you keep the baby warm?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/dry_newborn
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/assess_the_newborn
questions.description: You keep the baby warm by removing wet towels and cover with dry cloth after assessing the baby.

answers.value: Remove wet towels and cover with dry cloth after assessing the baby
Cover with dry cloth without assessing the baby
Cover with wet towels as this is good for the baby’s skin

questions.question: When should you start neonatal bag and mask resuscitation?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/ventilation_mask
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/assess_the_newborn
questions.description: You start resuscitating the newborn if not crying well or not breathing despite stimulation within the first minute of life.

answers.value: If crying loudly and moving the chest quickly
If heart rate is above 100 beats per minutes
Within the first minute of life if not crying well or not breathing despite stimulation.

questions.question: How do you know if the newborn is stable so you can proceed to routine initial care?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/dry_newborn
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/assess_the_newborn
questions.description:
You know that the newborn is stable so you can proceed to routine initial care:

If it is crying and breathing well with good colour.

If it is moving its arms and legs with a good tone.

If it has a heart rate above 100 beats per minute.

answers.value: If it is crying and breathing well with good colour
If it is moving its arms and legs with a good tone
If it has a heart rate above 100 beats per minute
If it has a heart rate above 60 beats per minute

questions.question: When should you clamp and cut the umbilical cord of a stable newborn?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/cord_clamping
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/clamp_and_cut_the_umbilical_cord
questions.description: You should clamp and cut the umbilical cord of a well looking newborn 1-3 minutes after birth or when the cord stops pulsating.

answers.value: 1-3 minutes after birth or when the cord stops pulsating

questions.question: How can you if you are a skilled provider assist the delivery of placenta?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/holding_the_cord_tight
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/controlled_cord_traction
questions.description: You can assist the delivery of the placenta by holding the cord tight and pulling it very gently parallel to the surface of the delivery bed during a contraction while the other hand pushes the uterus in the other direction.

answers.value: By holding the cord tight and pulling it very gently parallel to the surface of the delivery bed during a contraction while the other hand pushes the uterus in the other direction
There is no need to assist the delivery of the placenta
By holding the cord tight and pulling it very gently parallel to the surface of the delivery bed in between contractions while the other hand pushes the uterus in the other direction
By holding the cord tight and pulling it very gently upwards

questions.question: When using controlled cord traction to deliver the placenta, you hold the cord tight with one hand. What should you do with the other hand?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/pulling_the_cord
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/controlled_cord_traction
questions.description: With the other hand you apply counter pressure above the pubic bone.

answers.value: Apply counter pressure above the pubic bone
Apply counter pressure at the top of the uterus

questions.question: What normally happens to the uterus and cord after 2-3 minutes of holding the cord tightly as a sign of a detached placenta?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/pulling_the_cord
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/controlled_cord_traction
questions.description: Normally after 2-3 minutes of holding the cord tightly as a sign of a detached placenta the uterus becomes rounded and the cord lengthens.

answers.value: The uterus becomes rounded and the cord lengthens
The uterus will expand and the cord shortens
The uterus will become flat and the cord lengthens

questions.question: How can the mother cooperate with the delivery of placenta?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/controlled_cord_traction
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/controlled_cord_traction
questions.description: The mother can cooperate with the delivery of placenta by pushing.

questions.question: What is the first thing to do after the delivery of the placenta?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/delivery_of_the_placenta
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/controlled_cord_traction
questions.description: The first thing to do after the delivery of the placenta is to feel whether the uterus is contracted and check for bleeding.

answers.value: Feel whether the uterus is contracted and check for bleeding
Check the condition of the newborn

questions.question: Is it important to measure the blood loss?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/vaginal_bleeding
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/controlled_cord_traction
questions.description: Yes, it is important to measure blood loss because your actions are determined by the amount of bleeding.

answers.value: Yes, because your actions are determined by the amount of bleeding
No, it is waste of time – the blood is lost and you should concentrate on resuscitation

questions.question: What are crucial parts of an examination of the placenta?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/examination_of_placenta
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/examine_the_placenta
questions.description:
Crucial parts of an examination of the placenta are:

Make sure the membranes are intact.

Make sure no tissue is missing on the maternal surface.

answers.value: Make sure the membranes are intact
Make sure no tissue is missing on the maternal surface
Measure the length of the umbilical cord

questions.question: What do you look for on the maternal surface of the placenta?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/maternal_surface_of_placenta
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/examine_the_placenta
questions.description: You look for missing tissue on the maternal surface of the placenta.

questions.question: 15 minutes after birth you can leave the mother and newborn if everything appears normal. True or False?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/observe_the_mother_and_newborn
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description: False. Do not leave mother and newborn unattended within the first hour after delivery of the placenta.

questions.question: Where and how should the newborn be placed after birth?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/newborn_on_a_blanket
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description: The newborn should be placed with skin to skin with the mother, covered with dry towel and a hat.

answers.value: Skin to skin with the mother, covered with dry towel and a hat
In a baby bed covered with a hat
With the family, the mother needs to rest

questions.question: What should you check for when assessing the mother every 15 minutes after birth?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/observe_the_mother_and_newborn
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description:
When assessing the mother every 15 minutes after birth  you check:

That the uterus is well contracted.

The BP, pulse and that the mother is in a stable condition.

That there is no excessive bleeding.

answers.value: That the uterus is well contracted
The BP, pulse and that the mother is in a stable condition
That there is no excessive bleeding
That she can walk without support

questions.question: How often should you check the mother’s condition after birth, if everything appears normal?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/palpation_of_uterus
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description: You should check the mother’s condition every 15 minutes for the first two hours after birth if everything appears normal.

answers.value: Every 5 minutes for the first hour
Every 10 minutes for the first hour
Every 15 minutes for the first two hours

questions.question: How often should you check the newborn’s condition after birth if everything appears normal?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/observe_the_mother_and_newborn
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description: You check the newborn’s condition every 15 minutes for the first two hours after birth if everything appears normal.

answers.value: Every 5 minutes for the first hour
Every 10 minutes for the first hour
Every 15 minutes for the first two hours

questions.question: What should you check when assessing the newborn every 15 minutes after birth?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/breastfeeding_child_and_midwife
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description:
When assessing the newborn every 15 minutes after birth you check:

That it is breathing well and has a good colour.

Tone and heart rate.

That it is kept warm and is breastfeeding well

answers.value: That it is breathing well and has a good colour

questions.question: If the cord is bleeding, you should:
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/cord_care_after_1_hour
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description: If the cord is bleeding you should re-tie it.

questions.question: What should you give the newborn after birth?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/newborn_on_a_blanket
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description:
After birth you give the newborn:

Apgar score.

Vitamin K.

questions.question: Why is breastfeeding initiated within an hour after birth important for the newborn?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/breastfeeding
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description:
Breastfeeding initiated within an hour after birth is important for the newborn because:

It helps the newborn to fully inflate the lungs.

It provides important nutrition to the newborn.

It strengthens the newborn’s immune system.

answers.value: It helps the newborn to fully inflate the lungs
It provides important nutrition to the newborn
It prepares the newborn for bottle feeding
It strengthens the newborn’s immune system

questions.question: Why is breastfeeding initiated within an hour after birth important for the mother?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/breastfeeding
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description: Breastfeeding initiated within an hour after birth is important for the mother because it stimulates the uterus to contract.

answers.value: It stimulates the uterus to contract
It strengthens the mother’s immune system
It protects her from getting pregnant again

questions.question: Identify some of the severe complications associated with prolonged labour for the mother:
questions.description:
Some of the severe complications associated with prolonged labour for the mother are:

Post-partum haemorrhage.

Uterine rupture.

Obstetric fistula.

questions.question: Identify some of the severe complications associated with prolonged labour for the infant:
questions.description:
Some of the severe complications associated with prolonged labour for the infant are:

Asphyxia.

Death.

Cerebral palsy.

questions.question: What are the 5 Ps that cause prolonged labour?
questions.description:
The 5 Ps that cause prolonged labour are:

Power, Pelvis, Passenger, Psyche, and Passing urine

answers.value: Power, Pelvis, Passenger, Psyche, and Passing urine
Power, Pelvis, Passenger, Pain, and Passing urine
Power, Prematurity, Pelvis,  Psyche, and Passing urine
Personality, Pelvis, Passenger, Preeclampsia, and Peeing

questions.question: What characterises a good contraction in active labour?
questions.description:
A good contraction in active labour is characterised by the following:

There are 3-5 in ten minutes.

They last 40 seconds or longer.

They are regular.

questions.question: The size of the pelvis is often the cause of prolonged labour. True or false?
questions.description: False, the size of the pelvis is not likely to be the cause of prolonged labour.

questions.question: What women are at risk of a narrow pelvis?
questions.description:
At risk of a narrow pelvis are:

Young girls.

Women with malformed pelvis due to severe malnutrition.

answers.value: Women with malformed pelvis due to severe malnutrition
Women who have had sexually transmitted diseases

questions.question: If you suspect a narrow pelvis during labour what will you pay extra attention to?
questions.description:
You can’t know during labour if the pelvis is too narrow for childbirth. 

You have to monitor progress by the Labour Care Guide.

answers.value: The progress - using the Labour Care Guide

questions.question: What is the normal presentation/rotation, when the head is at the pelvic floor?
questions.description:
The normal presentation/rotation, when the head is at the pelvic floor, is:

Cephalic occiput anterior.

answers.value: B - Cephalic head bent to the side

questions.question: How does psyche influence vaginal birth?
questions.description:
Psyche influence vaginal birth in the following way:

Anxiety and stress release adrenalin that weaken contractions.

answers.value: Anxiety and stress release adrenalin that weaken contractions

questions.question: What is true about pushing?
questions.description:
The following is true about pushing:

It should not last more than one hour.

It is the most stressful part of labour.

Foetal heart rate must be assessed closely.

answers.value: It should not last more than one hour
It is the most stressful part of labour
Foetal heart rate must be assessed closely
There is no upper limit for duration

questions.question: For how long time is it appropriate to push?
questions.description: It is appropriate to push for 1 hour for nullipara and 30 min for multipara.

questions.question: What are the most important indications for vacuum extraction?
questions.description:
The most important indications for vacuum extraction are:

Prolonged second stage.

Maternal exhaustion.

Foetal distress.

questions.question: While pushing, how often should foetal heart rate be assessed?
questions.description: While pushing, foetal heart rate should be assessed after each contraction or at least every 5 minutes.

answers.value: After each contraction or at least every 5 minutes

questions.question: When should FHR be assessed in relation to contractions?
questions.description: FHR should be assessed when the contraction is over.

answers.value: It doesn’t matter as long as you do it every 5 minutes

questions.question: What are prerequisites for vacuum extraction?
questions.description:
Prerequisites for vacuum extraction are:

The head must only be palpable one fifth above the pubic bone.

Cervix fully dilated and membranes ruptured.

Gestational age 36 weeks or more.

answers.value: The head must only be palpable one fifth above the pubic bone
Only apply at occiput anterior position
Cervix fully dilated and membranes ruptured

questions.question: What are complications to vacuum delivery?
questions.description:
Complications to vacuum delivery are:

Trauma to the birth canal.

Anal sphincter damage.

Minor trauma to the foetal head.

Post-partum haemorrhage.

answers.value: Minor trauma to the foetal head

questions.question: Before vacuum delivery what are important preparations?
questions.description:
Before vacuum delivery important preparations are:

Empty bladder.

Abdominal palpation.

Informed consent.

questions.question: When should you give up on a vacuum delivery?
questions.description:
You should give up on a vacuum delivery...

After 3 pop-offs.

If 3 pulls show no progress.

If birth not achieved after 30 minutes from application.

answers.value: If birth not achieved after 30 minutes from application

questions.question: At vacuum delivery episiotomy is often necessary, true or false?
questions.description: False, at vacuum delivery episiotomy is not often necessary.

questions.question: Within how long time from delivery of the baby should the placenta be delivered?
questions.description: The placenta should be delivered within 30 minutes from delivery of the baby.

questions.question: What is the treatment for retained placenta?
questions.description: The treatment for retained placenta is manual removal.

questions.question: Bleeding with a retained placenta is very dangerous. True or False?
questions.description: True, bleeding with a retained placenta is very dangerous.

questions.question: What is the order of actions at bleeding before delivery of the placenta?
questions.description:
The correct order of actions at bleeding before delivery of the placenta is: 
1. Call for help
2. Perform rapid initial assessment and start emergency management
3. Stop bleeding
4. Manual removal

answers.value: Perform rapid initial assessment and start emergency management

questions.question: What are signs of shock due to bleeding?
questions.description:
Signs of shock due to bleeding are: 

Pulse above 110

Cold sweats

Systolic blood pressure below 90

questions.question: What  pain  relief  drugs  can  you  give  before  manual  removal  of  placenta?
questions.description: You can give Diazepam or Morphine IM or IV before manual removal of placenta

questions.question: How can you see if the compression is adequate when doing Aorta Compression?
questions.description: The bleeding with stop if you do an adequate Aorta Compression.

answers.value: The woman’s head will become pale and blue

questions.question: How long is aorta compression maintained during transport in case of referral?
questions.description: Aorta compression is maintained continously during transfer.

answers.value: Until IV access is established and resuscitation started

questions.question: How much intravenous, crystalloids fluid do you give at post-partum haemorrhage?
questions.description: You give 1-2 litres or more of intravenous, crystalloids fluid at post-partum haemorrhage. Give it fast and one bag at a time!

answers.value: 1-2 litres or more fast (one bag at a time)

questions.question: What can be done to make the intravenous (IV) fluids flow fast?
questions.description: You can make the intravenous fluids go in fast by compressing the bag with the hand or use of a blood pressure cuff.

answers.value: Compress the bag with the hand or use blood pressure cuff
Puncture the bag in the top

questions.question: What should you do if blood transfusion is available at your health facility?
questions.description: If blood transfusion is available at your health facility, you should take blood for blood type and cross-match.

answers.value: Take blood for blood type and cross-match

questions.question: What could be relevant analgesic drugs and drugs for relaxation for Manual removal of the placenta?
questions.description:
Relevant analgesic drugs and drugs for relaxation for Manual removal of the placenta could be:

Morphine

Diazepam

questions.question: Should you stop the aorta compression while giving pain relief?
questions.description: You should not stop the aorta compression while giving pain relief.

answers.value: Never start aorta compression until after proper pain relief
Yes, now you can end the aorta compression

keyLearningPoints.description: Gloves and manual removal of placenta

questions.question: What kind of gloves can be used for manual removal of the placenta?
questions.description: Either sterile elbow-long gloves, or normal sterile gloves, or examination gloves can be used for manual removal of the placenta.

keyLearningPoints.description: Right order for removal of placenta

questions.question: Once inside the uterus, how do you remove the placenta?
questions.description:
Once inside the uterus, you remove the placenta in the following way:

Use the edge of your flat hand to gently separate the placenta from the uterus.

Move the hand from side to side, once the placenta is loose, you gently pull it out.

answers.value: Use the edge of your flat hand to gently separate the placenta from the uterus
Move the hand from side to side, once the placenta is lose, you gently pull it out
Pull the placenta out with your fingers
Use your hands like claws and mash the placenta

questions.question: What is recommended to do right after manual removal of placenta?
questions.description:
Right after removal of placenta it is recommended to:

Massage the fundus to stimulate the uterus to contract
If still bleeding perform bimanual compression

answers.value: Refer the patient if she is still bleeding
Massage the fundus to stimulate the uterus to contract
If still bleeding perform bimanual compression

keyLearningPoints.description: The overall action to control PPH

questions.question: If you can’t remove the placenta completely you should
questions.description:
If you can’t remove the placenta completely you should

Apply uterine balloon tamponade.

Continue aorta compression if still bleeding.

Refer to a higher level health facility together with a health professional.

answers.value: Continue aorta compression if still bleeding
Refer to a higher level health facility together with a health professional
Refer to a higher level health facility unaccompanied

questions.question: When should you apply a uterine balloon tamponade (UBT)?
questions.description: You should apply a uterine balloon tamponade (UBT) in a situation where a bleeding doesn’t stop despite all possible non-surgical actions.

answers.value: In a situation where a bleeding doesn’t stop despite all possible non-surgical actions
All women bleeding more than 1 L must have a UBT for a minimum of 24 hours

questions.question: After manual removal of the placenta give the following drugs
questions.description:
After manual removal of the placenta give the following drugs:

Oxytocin drip 20 IU in 1 l of Normal Saline or Hartmann’s solution 

Tranexamic Acid 1 g IV slowly and Ergometrine 0.2 mg IV or IM

Ampicillin 2 g IV or 1 g Ceftriaxone IV

answers.value: Oxytocin drip 20 IU in 1 l of Normal Saline or Hartmann’s solution
Tranexamic Acid 1 g IV slowly and Ergometrine 0.2 mg IV or IM
Ampicillin 2 g IV or 1 g Ceftriaxone IV

questions.question: After the bleeding is controlled you:
questions.description:
After the bleeding is controlled you:

Monitor closely for the next 24 hours

Measure level of haemoglobin the next day (if test is available)

Recommend an iron supplement 120 mg twice daily for 3 months

answers.value: Monitor closely for the next 24 hours
Measure level of haemoglobin the next day (if test is available)
Recommend an iron supplement 120 mg twice daily for 3 months

questions.question: Is it safe to refer a woman with a retained placenta?
questions.description:
No! There is a high risk she will not survive the referral. Bleeding can be overwhelming.

Manual removal of the placenta is a Basic Emergency Obstetric and Neonatal Care signal function – and must be performed by any skilled birth attendant.

answers.value: No! There is a high risk she will not survive the referral. Bleeding can be overwhelming.
Manual removal of the placenta is a Basic Emergency Obstetric and Neonatal Care signal function – and must be performed by any skilled birth attendant
YES! The management is safest when performed at a high level health facility

questions.question: What are the most common causes of death amongst newborns?
questions.description:
The most common causes of death amongst newborns are:

Preterm birth.

Asphyxia.

Infections.

questions.question: Which statement is true?
questions.description: Most newborn deaths are avoidable, true.

answers.value: Most newborn deaths are not avoidable

questions.question: When do most newborn deaths occur?
questions.description: Most newborn deaths occur within the first week of life.

answers.value: Within the first week of life
Within the first 2-4 weeks of life
After the first month of life

questions.question: How do you prevent respiratory distress in newborns at preterm labour (GA 28-34 or estimated birth weight below 2 kg)?
questions.description: You prevent respiratory distress in newborns at preterm labour (GA 28-34 or estimated birth weight below 2 kg) by giving the mother Dexamethasone.

questions.question: What is the correct dose and administration of Dexamethasone?
questions.description:
The correct dose and administration of Dexamethasone is:
12 mg IM twice with 24 hours apart

answers.value: 12 mg IM twice with 24 hours apart
24 mg IM twice with 24 hours apart

questions.question: What are the maternal risk factors associated with newborn infection?
questions.description:
The maternal risk factors associated with newborn infections are: 

Preterm prelabour rupture of membranes (PPROM) 

Prelabour rupture of membranes (PROM) more than 18 hours before labour

Intrapartum fever

Foul-smelling vaginal discharge

answers.value: Prelabour rupture of membranes (PROM) more than 18 hours before labour

questions.question: How do you prevent newborn infections if risk factors are present?
questions.description:
To prevent newborn infections if risk factors are present, you:

Give antibiotics to the mother.

Give antibiotics to the newborn.

answers.value: Perform Active Management of Third Stage of Labor

questions.question: If you do not remember the dosages of antibiotics to the newborn, what do you do?
questions.description: If you do not remember the dosages of antibiotics to the newborn, you look in the Safe Delivery App film on Newborn Management or in the drug list.

answers.value: Look in the Safe Delivery App film on Newborn Management or in the drug list
Give what you think is the correct dose
Discharge the newborn and ask the mother to return if danger signs

questions.question: What is the dosage of Ampicillin and Gentamicin?
questions.description:
The dosage of Ampicillin and Gentamicin is:
Ampicillin 50 mg per kg IV or IM twice daily and Gentamicin 5 mg per kg IV or IM once daily.

answers.value: Ampicillin 50 mg per kg IV or IM twice daily and Gentamicin 5 mg per kg IV or IM once daily
Ampicillin 5 mg per kg IV or IM twice daily and Gentamicin 50 mg per kg IV/IM once daily

questions.question: What is a newborn who has been resuscitated at risk of?
questions.description:
A newborn who has been resuscitated is at risk of:

Low blood sugar.

Respiratory distress.

Seizures.

questions.question: A newborn has been resuscitated successfully and is stable. What are the next actions?
questions.description:
A newborn has been resuscitated successfully and is stable. The next actions are:

Ensure breastfeeding within 1 hour after birth. 

Keep warm by skin to skin contact with the mother.

Monitor closely for danger signs.

answers.value: Ensure breastfeeding within 1 hour after birth
Keep warm by skin to skin contact with the mother
Wrap to keep warm and give the newborn to a relative

questions.question: When should breastfeeding start after birth?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/breastfeeding
questions.description: Breastfeeding should start within the first hour after birth.

answers.value: Within the first hour after birth
Within the first two hours after birth
Within the first 12 hours after birth

questions.question: Which newborns need initial care after delivery?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/dry_newborn
questions.description: All newborns need initial care after delivery.

questions.question: After delivery and stimulation, a newborn is not crying or breathing well, what do you do?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/brand_new_baby
questions.description: If a newborn is not crying or breathing well after delivery and stimulation, proceed to neonatal resuscitation.

answers.value: Counsel the mother on her loss
Place the newborn skin to skin with the mother

keyLearningPoints.description: Initial care of the newborn actions

questions.question: Initial care of the newborn (above 1500 g) includes amongst others which of the following?
questions.description:
Initial care of the newborn (above 1500 g) includes amongst others the following:

Check breathing and colour every 15  minutes.

Check the cord for bleeding every 15 min, keep it clean and dry.

Give 1 mg vitamin K (IM).

answers.value: Check breathing and colour every 15  minutes
Check the cord for bleeding every 15 min, keep it clean and dry

questions.question: A newborn is delivered prematurely and weighs less than 2.5 kg. What do you do?
questions.description:
If a newborn is delivered prematurely and weighs less than 2.5 kg, you do the following:

Resuscitate if necessary.

When stable consider referral to facility with advanced care.

Admit and monitor closely for danger signs while ensuring skin to skin contact with the mother is maintained.

answers.value: Wait and see if it survives
When stable consider referral to facility with advanced care
Admit and monitor closely for danger signs while ensuring skin to skin contact with the mother is maintained

questions.question: A preterm newborn is unable to suck adequately what should you do?
questions.description:
If a preterm newborn is unable to suck adequately, you:

Feed by cup or nasogastric tube.

Consider referral to facility with advanced care.

answers.value: Feed by cup or nasogastric tube
Provide counselling to the mother, the newborn is unlikely to survive
Consider referral to facility with advanced care

questions.question: Which statement is true?
questions.description: The signs of serious illness in newborns are difficult to identify - true.

answers.value: The signs of serious illness in newborns are difficult to identify.
The signs of serious illness in newborns are easy to identify.

questions.question: What is meant by “danger signs” with regards to newborns?
questions.description: “Danger signs” with regards to newborns means signs of serious illness.

answers.value: Signs indicating that the mother is not able to care for the newborn

questions.question: What does management of “A, B, C” stand for?
questions.description: Management of A, B, C stands for Airway, Breathing and Circulation.

questions.question: An unconscious newborn is brought to the clinic. Place the following actions in the correct order:
questions.description:
An unconscious newborn is brought to the clinic. The correct order of the actions is:
1. Call for help!
2. Manage Airway
3. Manage Breathing
4. Manage Circulation

questions.question: What do you need to observe when assessing “A” for Airway in management of A, B, C?
questions.description:
When assessing “A” for Airway in management of A, B, C, you need to observe:

If airway is obstructed.

If airway is free and safe.

answers.value: If airway is free and safe

questions.question: What are the breathing danger signs in newborns?
questions.description:
The breathing danger signs in newborns are:

Respiratory rate slower than 30 per minute or faster than 60 per minute.

Severe chest in drawings.

Grunting.

answers.value: Respiratory rate slower than 30 per minute or faster than 60 per minute

questions.question: A newborn has a respiratory rate below 30 breaths per minute, what do you do?
questions.description: If the respiratory rate is below 30 breaths per minute, start bag and mask ventilation.

answers.value: Place it skin to skin with the mother

questions.question: What is grunting in a newborn?
questions.description: Grunting is when the newborn’s chest is moving unnaturally and the newborn has a sound on its breathing.

answers.value: The newborn’s chest is moving unnaturally and the newborn makes a sound while breathing
It is crying due to being hungry
It is pale due to being cold
It is red due to fever

questions.question: What is apnoea in a newborn?
questions.description: Apnoea in a newborn means that the newborn is not breathing for more than 20 seconds.

answers.value: No breathing for more than 20 seconds
Respiratory rate faster than 60 per minute
Respiratory rate less than 30 per minute
Capillary refill time more than 3 seconds

questions.question: What are the signs of shock?
questions.description:
The signs of shock in a newborn are:

Pale colour and weak pulse.

Heart rate below 80 or above 180.

Capillary refill time of more than 3 seconds.

answers.value: Capillary refill time of more than 3 seconds

questions.question: If a newborn has a heart rate of 200 and pale colour what is it showing signs of?
questions.description: If a newborn has a heart rate of 200 and pale colour, it is showing signs of shock.

questions.question: Which of the following are danger signs in a newborn?
questions.description:
The following are danger signs in a newborn:

Poor feeding or inability to suck.

Decreased consciousness.

Vomiting.

answers.value: Poor feeding or inability to suck

questions.question: Which of the following are danger signs in a newborn?
questions.description:
The following are danger signs in a newborn:

Convulsions.

Decreased muscle tone.

Irritability.

questions.question: Choose the danger signs of exposure in a newborn.
questions.description:
The danger signs of exposure in a newborn are:

Temperature below 36.5˚C or above 37.5˚C.

Red tender umbilicus.

Severe jaundice.

questions.question: What is severe jaundice in a newborn?
questions.description:
Severe jaundice in a newborn is:
A yellowish tone that appears on the face during the first day of life or extends to the palms and soles at any time.

answers.value: A yellowish tone that appears on the face during the first day of life or extends to the palms and soles at any time
A yellowish tone that appears on the face and extends to the palms and soles during the first day

questions.question: A newborn is two weeks old, the mother says it is not feeding well, the heart rate is 200 and it has a capillary refill time of 4 seconds. Place the following actions in order:
questions.description:
A newborn is two weeks old, the mother says it is not feeding well, the heart rate is 200 and it has a capillary refill time of 4 seconds. The correct order of the actions is:

1.     Call for help and make sure airway is free and safe. If obstructed, suction. 
2.     Start bag and mask ventilation if the newborn is not breathing or has a respiratory rate of below 30 per minute.
3.     Give fluid therapy, 10ml per kg normal saline intravenously over 10 minutes. Repeat if necessary.
4.     Give first dose of antibiotics and consider referral to facility with advanced care.

answers.value: Call for help and make sure airway is free and safe. If obstructed, suction
Start bag and mask ventilation if the newborn is not breathing or has a respiratory rate of below 30 per minute
Give fluid therapy, 10ml per kg normal saline intravenously over 10 minutes. Repeat if necessary
Give first dose of antibiotics and consider referral to facility with advanced care

questions.question: You suspect that a two-week-old newborn has an infection but are not quite sure. What do you do?
questions.description: If you suspect that a two-week-old newborn has an infection but are not quite sure, you act fast and treat on little suspicion.

answers.value: Act fast and treat on little suspicion
Ask the mother to return if the newborn is getting worse

questions.question: A newborn has an obstructed airway, what do you do?
questions.description: If the airway is obstructed, position so airway is free and use suction.

questions.question: A newborn has a bluish colour and difficulty breathing. What do you do?
questions.description: If a newborn has a bluish colour and difficulty breathing, you give oxygen by nasal catheter or prongs if available.

answers.value: Give oxygen by nasal catheter or prongs if available.
Wait and see if the respiration normalizes spontaneously

questions.question: A newborn is drowsy and unconscious. What do you do?
questions.description: If a newborn is drowsy and unconscious, you check blood glucose. If you cannot measure, assume low blood sugar and treat.

answers.value: Check blood glucose. If you cannot measure, assume low blood sugar and treat.
Counsel the mother on the loss of her newborn

questions.question: What is the correct treatment of low blood sugar in a newborn?
questions.description:
The correct treatment of low blood sugar in a newborn is: 

Give 10 % glucose 2 ml per kg IV. 

Alternatively give expressed breast milk or 10% glucose 10 ml per kg by nasogastric tube.

answers.value: Give 10 % glucose 2 ml per kg IV
Alternatively give expressed breast milk or 10% glucose 10 ml per kg by nasogastric tube
Give 10 % glucose 10 ml per kg IV

questions.question: A newborn is having convulsions for more than 3 minutes. The blood sugar is 1.5. Place the following actions in order:
questions.description:
A newborn is having convulsions for more than 3 minutes. The blood sugar is 1.5. The correct order of the actions is:

1.     Give 10 % glucose 2 ml per kg IV. Alternatively give expressed breast milk or 10% glucose 10 ml per kg by nasogastric tube.

2.     Phenobarbital 20 mg per kg IV or IM. 

3.     Give first dose of antibiotics.

4.     Consider referral to facility with advanced care.

answers.value: Give 10 % glucose 2 ml per kg IV. Alternatively give expressed breast milk or 10% glucose 10 ml per kg by nasogastric tube
Phenobarbital 20 mg per kg IV or IM
Consider referral to facility with advanced care

questions.question: A newborn is having convulsions and you cannot measure blood glucose. What should you do?
questions.description:
If a newborn is having convulsions and you cannot measure blood glucose, you do the following:

Assume low blood sugar and treat.

Give Phenobarbital 20 mg/kg IV/IM.

Consider referral to facility with advanced care after providing initial care and stabilizing the newborn.

answers.value: Assume low blood sugar and treat
Refer immediately to facility with advanced care
Consider referral to facility with advanced care after providing initial care and stabilizing the newborn

questions.question: What is the maximum total dosage of Phenobarbital for a newborn?
questions.description: The maximum total dosage of Phenobarbital for a newborn is 40 mg/kg.

questions.question: If the newborn has jaundice what should you do?
questions.description:
If the newborn has jaundice, you do the following:

Confirm with a bilirubin measurement and treat with phototherapy.

Refer to facility with advanced care.

answers.value: Confirm with a bilirubin measurement and treat with phototherapy
Refer to facility with advanced care
Place the newborn without clothes under the sun

questions.question: A newborn has a temperature of 36 degrees. What do you do?
questions.description: If a newborn has a temperature of 36 degrees, you warm up with skin to skin contact with mother and check for danger signs.

answers.value: Warm up with skin to skin contact with mother
Ventilate with a bag and mask
Give 10 % glucose 2 ml per kg IV. Alternatively give expressed breast milk or glucose 10 ml per kg by nasogastric tube

questions.question: You should suspect a severe infection and give antibiotics to a newborn if:
questions.description: You should suspect a severe infection and give antibiotics to a newborn if there are any danger signs at all.

answers.value: There are any danger signs at all
There are three or more danger signs
The mother is concerned about her newborn

questions.question: If the newborn’s condition does not improve within 2 days what should you do?
questions.description: If the newborn’s condition does not improve within 2 days, you should change treatment to broader antibiotics, usually Ceftriaxone 100 mg per kg IV or IM once daily.

answers.value: Change treatment to broader antibiotics, usually Ceftriaxone 100 mg per kg IV or IM once daily
Stop antibiotic treatment and discharge for care at home

questions.question: A newborn with danger signs is at risk of low blood sugar. How would you prevent this?
questions.description: A newborn with danger signs is at risk of low blood sugar. To prevent this risk, you keep the newborn warm by skin to skin contact with the mother and increase feeding frequency to every 2 hours.

answers.value: Keep warm by skin to skin contact with the mother
Increase feeding frequency to every 2 hours

questions.question: If a newborn is unable to suck, how can you administer expressed breastmilk?
questions.description:
If a newborn is unable to suck, you can administer expressed breastmilk?

In a cup.

By nasogastric tube.

If expressed milk is not possible or the newborn vomits give glucose 10% 2 ml per kg/hour (IV).

answers.value: If expressed milk is not possible or the newborn vomits give glucose 10% 2 ml per kg/hour (IV).

questions.question: Your facility is rural and has limited treatment options, and a newborn is brought in with danger signs. What should you do?
questions.description: If your facility is rural and has limited treatment options, and a newborn is brought in with danger signs, you should give a first dose of antibiotics and refer urgently to a facility with advanced care.

answers.value: Give first dose of antibiotics and refer urgently to a facility with advanced care
Admit the newborn and monitor closely
Give first dose of antibiotics and ensure that the mother returns the next day

questions.question: Failure to initiate adequate breathing for a newborn at birth is a common cause of:
questions.description: Failure to initiate adequate breathing at birth is a common cause of neonatal death.

questions.question: The golden minute implies that all newborns by one minute of age, should:
questions.description:
The golden minute implies that all newborns should by one minute of age:

Breathe on their own.

If not breathing be ventilated with a bag and a mask.

answers.value: Move their arms and legs with a good tone
If not breathing be ventilated with a bag and a mask
Lie skin to skin with the mother

questions.question: When do you assess a newborn after birth?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/brand_new_baby
questions.description: You assess a newborn immediately after delivery.

answers.value: After the umbilical cord is cut

questions.question: Where do you place the newborn immediately after birth?
questions.description: Immediately after birth you place the newborn on the mother with skin to skin contact.

answers.value: On the mother with skin to skin contact
Set it down in between the legs of the mother while you care for her
In a warm cloth away from the mother

questions.question: What is the first steps you take after the baby is born?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/brand_new_baby
questions.description: The first steps you take after the newborn is born is to dry the newborn and assess the newborn’s colour, tone and check if it is crying and breathing well.

answers.value: Dry the newborn and assess the newborn’s colour, tone and check if it is crying and breathing well
Suction the baby’s mouth and nose
Start ventilating with a ventilation bag

questions.question: Which statement is true?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/green_newborn
questions.description: Only babies born with thick meconium or with secretions blocking the mouth and nose need suction at birth.

answers.value: Only babies born with thick meconium or with secretions blocking the mouth and nose need suction at birth

questions.question: If a baby is born with thick meconium and needs resuscitation, in what order would you act?
questions.description:
If a baby is born with thick meconium and needs resuscitation, you act in the following order:

1.	Dry thoroughly.

2.	Suction.

3.	Ventilate.

questions.question: What do you do immediately after the delivery of a vigorously crying newborn?
questions.description:
Immediately after the delivery you:

Dry the baby with a towel. 

Stimulate the baby by rubbing the back.

Remove wet towels and cover the newborn to keep it warm.

answers.value: Dry the baby with a towel
Stimulate the baby by rubbing the back
Remove wet towels and cover the newborn to keep it warm

questions.question: Immediately after birth you find that the newborn is not breathing well. What do you do next?
questions.description: If immediately after birth you find that the newborn is not breathing well, you stimulate the baby by drying and rubbing the back with a dry cloth.

answers.value: Stimulate the baby by drying and rubbing the back with a dry cloth
Suction the baby’s mouth and nose

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true? The newborn needs resuscitation if:
questions.description: The newborn needs resuscitation if, within the first minute after delivery and after thorough stimulation it is gasping or not crying or breathing.

answers.value: Within the first minute  after delivery and after thorough stimulation it is gasping or not crying or breathing
Within 2 minutes after delivery it is gasping or not crying or not breathing

questions.question: The newborn is not responding to stimulation by drying and rubbing the back. Place the following three immediate actions in order:
questions.description:
If the newborn is not responding to stimulation by drying and rubbing the back, your actions should be:

1. Call for help
2. Position the head in a "sniffing position to open the airway
3. Give ventilation breaths (40 breaths per minute)

answers.value: Position the head in a "sniffing" position to open the airway
Give ventilation breaths (40 breaths per minute).

questions.question: When performing resuscitation, you place the head in a "sniffing" position. What is the "sniffing" head position?
questions.description: The "sniffing" head position is when a folded or rolled cloth is under the shoulders with the neck slightly.

answers.value: A folded or rolled cloth under the shoulders with the next slightly extended
The neck is hyperextended backwards to open the airway
Head is to the side to let fluids escape

questions.question: Where do you place the mask on the newborn?
questions.description: You place the mask on the mouth and nose.

answers.value: On the eyes, mouth and nose

questions.question: How do you ensure that ventilation is effective?
questions.description: You ensure that ventilation is effective be making sure that the chest rises with every ventilation.

answers.value: Make sure that the chest rises with every ventilation
Make sure that the bag is emptied every breath
Make sure to press very hard on the bag
Make sure to ventilate very fast

questions.question: How often do you re-evaluate the breathing during ventilation?
questions.description: You re-evaluate the breathing during resuscitation continously and at least every minute.

answers.value: Continuously and at least every minute
Only when the newborn starts breathing well

questions.question: How do you perform a jaw thrust?
questions.description: You perform a jaw thrust by lifting the baby’s jaw forward with one hand.

answers.value: Lift the baby’s jaw forward with one hand
Apply force on the mask on the newborn’s jaw
Suction the newborn’s mouth and nose

questions.question: The chest is not rising during your attempts to ventilate the newborn. What do you do?
questions.description:
If the chest is not rising during your attempts to ventilate the newborn:

Reposition the head and lift the newborn’s jaw forward.

Reapply the mask and squeeze the bag harder

answers.value: Wait and see if the respiration is restored spontaneously
Reposition the head and lift the newborn’s jaw forward
Reapply the mask and squeeze the bag harder

questions.question: When should you stop suctioning the newborn?
questions.description: You should stop suctioning when secretions are cleared.

answers.value: When the newborn starts to breathe

questions.question: What are ventilation breaths?
questions.description: Ventilation breaths are ventilating the newborn at a rate of 40 breaths per minute– with each breath you say “1-2-3”.

answers.value: Ventilating the newborn at a rate of 40 breaths per minute– with each breath you say “1-2-3”
The first 5 slow ventilations in neonatal resuscitation – each breath is sustained for 2-3 seconds while the chest moves
The first spontaneous breaths the newborn takes unassisted on its own

questions.question: At what rate do you give ventilation breaths?
questions.description: You give ventilation breaths with approximately 40 breaths per minute.

questions.question: After one minute of ventilating, the newborn is breathing less than 30 breaths/minute, or the heart rate is below 100 beats per min. What is your next action?
questions.description:
If after 1 minute of ventilating, the newborn is breathing less than 30 breaths/minute, or the heart rate is below 100 beats per min. 
- you continue ventilation breaths.

answers.value: Wait and see if the respiration is restored spontaneously
Stimulation by drying and rubbing the back.
Stop resuscitation and counsel the mother on her loss

questions.question: When do you continue with ventilation breaths?
questions.description:
You continue with ventilation breaths when:

Respiratory rate less than 30 times/minute.

Heart rate below 100 beats per minute.

answers.value: Heart rate below 100 beats per minute

questions.question: What is most important thing to keep in mind regarding ventilation breaths?
questions.description: It is most important thing to keep in mind that you know the ventilation technique is effective when you can see chest movements.

answers.value: That you know the ventilation technique is effective when you can see chest movements
That you apply force on the mask to ensure a good seal
That you wrap the newborn in a warm cloth

questions.question: How do you ensure an even rhythm in ventilation breaths?
questions.description:
You do following to ensure an even rhythm in ventilation breaths:

Count out loud: “One—two—three” as you ventilate the newborn.

Squeeze the bag as you say “one” and release the pressure on the bag as you say “two—three.”

answers.value: Squeeze the bag three times every time you say “breathe - two – three”
Count out loud: “One—two—three” as you ventilate the newborn
Squeeze the bag as you say “One” and release the pressure on the bag as you say “two—three.”

questions.question: How do you correctly ventilate a newborn?
questions.description:
You correctly ventilate a newborn by:

Make sure that the mask is well sealed to the newborn.

Look for adequate chest rise.

Allow the lungs to recover between each inflation.

answers.value: Make sure that the mask is well sealed to the newborn
Allow the lungs to recover between each inflation
Make sure the newborn has a gastric tube

questions.question: When do you assess the newborn during resuscitation?
questions.description: You assess the newborn during resuscitation every minute.

questions.question: What do you assess during neonatal resuscitation?
questions.description:
During neonatal resuscitation you assess:

Breathing.

Colour and tone.

Heart rate.

questions.question: If the newborn has not established regular breathing or the pulse is below 100 bpm after one minute of ventilation breaths, what do you do?
questions.description: If the newborn has not established regular breathing or the pulse is below 100 bpm you continue ventilation breaths.

answers.value: Wait and see if the respiration is restored spontaneously

questions.question: When the newborn is breathing well, it has normal colour, normal tone, and a heart rate above 100 bpm, in what order would you do the following actions?
questions.description:
You do the following actions:

1. Stop ventilation and continue observation for 5 minutes.

2. Place the newborn skin-to-skin with the mother 

3. Establish early breastfeeding

4. Every 15 minutes for the first 2 hours, you check colour, tone, breathing, heart rate, and that the newborn is warm.

answers.value: Stop ventilation and continue observation for 5 minutes.
Place the newborn skin-to-skin with the mother
Every 15 minutes for the first 2 hours, you check colour, tone, breathing, heart rate, and that the newborn is warm

questions.question: The respiratory rate is normal. But what do you do if the newborn’s colour is bluish or if the newborn is having difficulty breathing with in-drawings or grunting?
questions.description: If the respiratory rate is normal and the newborn’s colour is bluish or if the newborn is having difficulty breathing with in-drawings or grunting, you give oxygen by nasal catheter or prongs if available.

answers.value: Give oxygen by nasal catheter or prongs if available
Wrap the newborn and give it to the mother

questions.question: When do you stop resuscitation?
questions.description:
You stop resuscitation:

When the newborn is breathing well, it has normal colour, normal tone, and a heart rate above 100 bpm.

If the newborn is not breathing and has no heart rate after 10 min of EFFECTIVE ventilation.

If the newborn has a heart rate below 60 bpm for more than 20 minutes you may take the difficult decision to stop the resuscitation.

answers.value: When the newborn is breathing well, it has normal colour, normal tone, and a heart rate above 100 bpm
If the newborn is not breathing and has no heart rate after 10 min of EFFECTIVE ventilation
If the newborn has a heart rate below 60 bpm for more than 20 minutes you may take the difficult decision to stop the resuscitation
If the newborn is not breathing and has no pulse after 2 min of EFFECTIVE ventilation

questions.question: What do you do after you have decided to stop an unsuccessful resuscitation of a newborn?
questions.description:
When you have stopped the resuscitation you:

Explain gently to the mother, that the newborn unfortunately did not survive.

Provide emotional support to the family.

answers.value: Explain gently to the mother, that the newborn unfortunately did not survive
Provide emotional support to the family
You leave the woman alone to grieve
You continue with your other duties

questions.question: The newborn is now crying with a good colour and tone. Select two immediate actions.
questions.description:
Two immediate actions when the newborn is crying with a good colour and tone are:

Place the newborn with mother skin-to-skin.

Early breastfeeding (within the first hour).

answers.value: Place the newborn with mother skin-to-skin
Wrap the newborn and place it with a relative

questions.question: How do you prevent hypoglycaemia if the newborn has been resuscitated for more than one minute?
questions.description:
You prevent hypoglycaemia for the resuscitated newborn by:

Establish breastfeeding within the first half hour.

After breastfeeding give supplementary feeding in a cup.

answers.value: Establish breastfeeding within the first half hour
After breastfeeding give supplementary feeding in a cup
Give the newborn exclusive formula milk

questions.question: How should you resuscitate a preterm newborn?
questions.description: You should resuscitate a preterm newborn with the same maneuvers as for full term newborns but with a smaller mask for ventilation.

answers.value: With the same maneuvers as for full term newborns but with a smaller mask for ventilation
Avoid inflation breaths in a preterm newborn – otherwise resuscitate in the same way as you would do with a term newborn

questions.question: What are the greatest challenges with regards to resuscitation of a small or preterm newborn?
questions.description:
The greatest challenges with regards to resuscitation of a small or preterm newborn are:

Adequate chest rise.

To ensure a correct seal of the mask and bag.

answers.value: To ensure a correct seal of the mask and bag

questions.question: Should soap be placed in a wet container?
questions.description: No, soap should not be placed in a wet container, because germs will grow.

answers.value: Yes, because when the soap is already wet, you save water

questions.question: Why is it not recommended to air-dry hands after hand wash?
questions.description: It is not recommended to air-dry hands after handwash, as almost no one can wait, so they dry their hands on their clothing unconsciously.

answers.value: Germs will grow while you wait
Almost no one can wait so they dry their hands on their clothing unconsciously
Because a shared towel will make hands cleaner

questions.question: How do you deliver the membranes following the placenta in the best way?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/placenta_in_uterus
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/controlled_cord_traction
questions.description: You deliver the membranes following the placenta in the best way by continuously rotating the placenta, so the membranes become like a rope.

answers.value: By continuously rotating the placenta, so the membranes become like a rope
By quick little pulls so the membranes separate gradually from the uterine wall

questions.question: What is true regarding blood loss?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/vaginal_bleeding
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/controlled_cord_traction
questions.description: Regarding blood loss it is true that you tend to underestimate the blood loss, because the amount looks smaller than it really is.

answers.value: You tend to underestimate the blood loss, because the amount looks smaller than it really is
You tend to overestimate the blood loss, because it is mixed with amniotic fluid and maybe urine

questions.question: What is correct regarding PPH?
questions.description:
Regarding PPH the following is correct:

It is one of the major causes of maternal death.

answers.value: It rarely affects women with a normal delivery
It is one of the major causes of maternal death
It will appear within the first 10 minutes after delivery

keyLearningPoints.description: Call for help. Then stop the bleeding.

questions.question: Prioritize the actions at strong bleeding until helpers arrive
questions.description:
At strong bleeding you should prioritise the following until helpers arrive:

1. Call for help and perform rapid initial assessment 

2. start emergency management by using the PPH bundle of care method 

3. Stop the bleeding

answers.value: Call for help and perform rapid initial assessment
Start emergency management by using the PPH bundle of care method

questions.question: What are the advantages of bimanual compression?
questions.description:
The advantages of bimanual compression are:

It provides pressure on the uterus so a bleeding due to lack of tone is controlled.

It can control the bleeding until helpers arrive.

It can reduce the bleeding from a cervical tear while the assistant prepares for suturing.

It cannot do any harm, but can on the other hand save lives.

answers.value: It provides pressure on the uterus so a bleeding due to lack of tone is controlled
It can control the bleeding until helpers arrive
It can reduce the bleeding from a cervical tear while the assistant prepares for suturing
It cannot do any harm, but can on the other hand save lives

Every 24 hours add to output 1 liter at no fever and 1½ liter at fever because of perspiration.

answers.value: Record all oral and intravenous input
Record all urinary, faeces and vomiting output
Every 24 hours add to output 1 liter at no fever and 1½ liter at fever because of perspiration

questions.question: At sepsis, without signs of septic shock, how often should the fluid balance be calculated?
questions.description: At sepsis, without signs of septic shock, the fluid balance be calculated each 8 hours.

questions.question: What should the fluid balance be?
questions.description: The fluid balance should be urine output of at least 400 ml per 8 hours.

answers.value: Urine output of at least 400 ml per 8 hours
Urine output at least 50 ml per 8 hours

keyLearningPoints.description: In case of a septic shock it should be calculated each hour.

questions.question: At septic shock how often should fluid balance be calculated?
questions.description: At septic shock the fluid balance should be calculated every hour.

questions.question: What are the important complications to sepsis?
questions.description:
The important complications to sepsis are:

Low blood pressure.

Multi organ failure.

questions.question: What is the order of actions for management of septic shock?
questions.description:
The order of actions for management of septic shock is: 

1. Call for help.

2. Assure free airway and breathing.

3. Assure circulation.

4. Administer drugs and evaluate for cause.

answers.value: Administer drugs and evaluate for cause

questions.question: How do you assure proper circulation in a patient with sepsis?
questions.description:
To assure proper circulation in a patient with sepsis, you: 

Insert 2 wide bore IV cannula.

Give 2 litres crystalloids IV in the first hour.  

Insert indwelling urine catheter and monitor in- and output.

answers.value: Give 2 litres crystalloids IV in the first hour
Insert indwelling urine catheter and monitor in- and output

questions.question: What antibiotics should be given?
questions.description: Broad-spectrum, intravenous antibiotics, for example Ampicillin, Gentamicin and Metronidazole should be given.

answers.value: Broad-spectrum, intravenous, for example Ampicillin, Gentamicin and Metronidazole

questions.question: What is the correct dosage for Ampicillin at sepsis?
questions.description:
The correct dosage for Ampicillin at sepsis is:

2 grams IV repeated each 6 hours.

questions.question: What is the correct dosage for Gentamicin at sepsis?
questions.description:
The correct dose for Gentamicin at sepsis is:

240 mg IV repeated each 24 hours.

questions.question: What is the correct dosage for Metronidazole at sepsis?
questions.description:
The correct dosage for Metronidazole at sepsis is: 

500 mg IV each 8 hours.

questions.question: What is the correct dosage of Gentamycin at sepsis?
questions.description:
The correct dosage of Gentamycin at sepsis is:

240 mg IV repeated every 24 hours

questions.question: What is the correct dosage of Tetracycline at sepsis?
questions.description: Tetracycline should be avoided for pregnant women. Other drugs are recommended.

answers.value: Tetracycline should be avoided for pregnant women. Other drugs are recommended.
Tetracycline is drug of choice, give 100 mg IV
Tetracycline is drug of choice, give 100 mg orally
Tetracycline is drug of choice, give 100 mg orally. Repeat each 6 hours for two days.

questions.question: What is the correct dosage of Chloramphenicol at sepsis?
questions.description:
Chloramphenicol should be avoided for pregnant and breastfeeding women.

Only if the benefits outweigh the risks and other relevant drugs are not available it could be considered.

answers.value: Chloramphenicol should be avoided for pregnant and breastfeeding women
Only if the benefits outweigh the risks and other relevant drugs are not available it could be considered
Chloramphenicol is drug of choice, give 500 mg orally each 8 hours
Chloramphenicol is drug of choice, give 500 mg intravenously each 6 hours

questions.question: If in a malaria area, how would you manage a septic patient?
questions.description:
If in a malaria area you should manage a septic patient in the following way:

Give anti-malarial treatment in addition to broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Have the patient take a malaria test if available before starting treatment if it causes no delay.

I would give anti-malarial treatment instead of broad-spectrum anti-bacterial treatment
I would give anti-malarial treatment after 24 hours with no effect of antibacterial treatment
I would have the patient take a malaria test if available before starting treatment if it causes no delay

questions.question: What drugs are appropriate for treating malaria at sepsis?

Appropriate drugs for treating malaria at sepsis are:

Artesuanate.

Quinine.

questions.question: How is Artesunate administered at sepsis?

Artesunate is administered at sepsis in the following way:

Intravenously.

Intramuscularly.

questions.question: How is Quinine administered at sepsis?
questions.description:
Quinine is administered at sepsis in the following way:

Intravenously.

Intramuscularly.

questions.question: What is the dosage of Artesunate?
questions.description:
The correct dosage of Artesunate is:

2.4 mg per kilo  IV or IM.

Repeat dose after 12 hours and then once daily until the patient may take oral medicine.

Repeat dose after 12 hours and then once daily until the patient may take oral medicine
4.8 mg per kilo weight IV or IM
200 mg orally. Repeat after 8 and 16 hours then every 24 hours for 7 days

10 mg/kg in 5% glucose IV over minimum 4 hours.

questions.question: What are the W’s you should think of as infectious focus at sepsis?
questions.description:
The W’s you should think of as infectious focus at sepsis are:

Womb.

Weaning.

Wind.

questions.question: What are the W’s you should think of as infectious focus at sepsis?
questions.description:
The W’s you should think of as infectious focus at sepsis are:

Water.

Wound.

Wings.

questions.question: What is an infection in the womb (uterus) called in a pregnant woman?
questions.description: An infection in the womb (uterus) in a pregnant woman is called Chorioamnionitis.

questions.question: What is an infection in the womb (uterus) called after delivery?
questions.description:
An infection in the womb (uterus) after delivery is called:

Endometritis.

Puerperal sepsis.

questions.question: What is the treatment for Chorioamnionitis?
questions.description:
The treatment for Chorioamnionitis is:

Delivery - Consider it an abscess.

Broad spectrum IV antibiotics.

questions.question: What is the treatment for endometritis?
questions.description:
The treatment for endometritis is:

Broad spectrum IV antibiotics.

If in an unstable condition or if no effect after 24 hours: evacuation of the uterus by MVA.

answers.value: If in an unstable condition or if no effect after 24 hours: evacuation of the uterus by MVA

keyLearningPoints.description: Endometritis and no effect of AB

questions.question: At suspected endometritis and no effect of antibiotic treatment after 24 hours, what will you do?
questions.description:
At suspected endometritis and no effect of antibiotic treatment after 24 hours, you do the following:

Perform evacuation of the uterus by MVA.

Perform a full body examination and reconsider other causes of infection.

answers.value: Perform evacuation of the uterus by MVA
Perform a full body examination and reconsider other causes of infection

questions.question: What is the treatment for mastitis?
questions.description:
The treatment for mastitis is:

Empty the breasts.

Flucloxacillin OR Clindamycin OR Erythromycin.

questions.question: At breast abscess what is the treatment?
questions.description:
At breast abscess the treatment is:

Empty the breasts.

Flucloxacillin OR Clindamycin OR Erythromycin.

Surgical drainage.

questions.question: How should a wound infection be treated?

Broad spectrum antibiotics and Dicloxacillin.

If no improvement after 24 hours the wound must be opened.

answers.value: If no improvement after 24 hours the wound must be opened
Cleaning with alcohol three times a day

questions.question: Other causes of infection apart from the 6 W’s could be:
questions.description:

Appendicitis (lower right quadrant pain).

Cholecystitis (Right upper quadrant pain).

Meningitis (Neck-stiffness).

questions.question: Is proteinuria a severe feature for preeclampsia?
questions.description: No, proteinuria is not a severe feature for preeclampsia.

questions.question: A pregnant woman with no proteinuria has a BP of 170/90. She has?
questions.description: A pregnant woman with no proteinuria and a BP of 170/90 has severe preeclampsia.

questions.question: Preeclampsia is often cured by itself during pregnancy. True or false?
questions.description: False, preeclampsia is not often cured by itself during pregnancy.

questions.question: What is the final cure for preeclampsia?
questions.description: The final cure for preeclampsia is termination of pregnancy.

questions.question: What is the most frequent cause of maternal death due to preeclampsia?
questions.description: The most frequent cause of maternal death due to preeclampsia is cerebral haemorrhage due to systolic hypertension.

answers.value: Cerebral haemorrhage due to systolic hypertension

questions.question: To prevent maternal death from preeclampsia the single most important action is to?
questions.description: To prevent maternal death from preeclampsia the single most important action is to keep systolic BP below 160.

answers.value: Give two litres of IV fluids FAST

questions.question: In case of eclampsia; in what order would you do the following actions?
questions.description:
In case of eclampsia; you should do the following actions:

1. Call for help and prevent the woman from trauma and tilt her to one side.

2. Give magnesium sulphate IV and manage hypertension.

3. Put in a urine catheter and write down output each hour. 

4. Monitor each half hour and plan delivery.

answers.value: Call for help and prevent the woman from trauma and tilt her to one side
Give magnesium sulphate IV and manage hypertension
Put in a urine catheter and write down output each hour
Monitor each half hour and plan delivery

Overloading fluids can cause pulmonary oedema.

Oliguria increases the risk of Magnesium Sulphate intoxication.

Oliguria increases the risk of Magnesium Sulphate intoxication

questions.description: The antidote to Magnesium Sulphate is Calcium Gluconate.

questions.question: What are important actions to take in order to provide successful ventilation breaths?

Position the head in the "sniffing" position.

Make sure that chest moves with every breath.

Be sure that no air is escaping from the mask

questions.question: When is a newborn considered low birth weight?

questions.question: What is Kangaroo Mother Care?

Continuous skin-to-skin contact for at least 20 hours a day

Continuous skin-to-skin contact for at least 20 hours a day

questions.question: How do you perform Kangaroo Mother Care?
questions.description:
You perform Kangaroo Mother Care by:
 
Dressing the newborn only in a diaper, hat, and socks.

Placing the newborn between the mother’s breasts in an upright position.

Tying the newborn securely to the mother with a cloth/binder.

Monitoring the newborn for warmth and regular breathing.

The newborn can breastfeed and is gaining weight.

The mother is competent in Kangaroo Mother Care.
