questions.question: What causes perinatal mental health conditions?
questions.description: Perinatal mental health conditions can be caused by changes in biology, psychology and the environment.

answers.value: Changes in psychology and the environment
Changes in the environment and biology
Changes in biology, psychology and the environment

keyLearningPoints.description: What are known risk factors of developing a mental health condition in the perinatal period?

questions.question: What are known risk factors of developing a mental health condition in the perinatal period?
questions.description: Living in areas of conflict, previous stillbirth or repeated miscarriage and unintended pregnancies are some of the risk factors of developing a perinatal mental health condition.

keyLearningPoints.description: Poverty decreases the likelihood of women experiencing postpartum depression or anxiety, true or false?

questions.question: Poverty decreases the likelihood of women experiencing postpartum depression or anxiety, true or false?
questions.description: It’s true that poverty increases the likelihood of women experiencing postpartum depression or anxiety.

keyLearningPoints.description: What are examples of useful screening tools for the detection of perinatal mental health conditions?

questions.question: What are examples of useful screening tools for the detection of perinatal mental health conditions?
questions.description: GAD-2, GAD-7 and the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale are examples of useful screening tools to help detect perinatal mental health conditions.

keyLearningPoints.description: What are treatment options for perinatal depression?

questions.question: What are treatment options for perinatal depression?
questions.description: Examples of treatments for perinatal depression are increasing social support networks, psychoeducation, and trauma informed care.

keyLearningPoints.description: The provision of perinatal mental health care often requires:

questions.question: The provision of perinatal mental health care often requires:
questions.description: Collaboration between health professionals is often required in order to provide effective perinatal mental health care.

answers.value: A judgemental attitude from her care provider
That the woman is separated from her family
That the woman and her baby are separated

keyLearningPoints.description: What is the first line management of a woman who has screened positive for perinatal depression?

questions.question: What is the first line management of a woman who has screened positive for perinatal depression?
questions.description: When a woman has screened positive for perinatal depression, first line management should be to engage in a therapeutic relationship with her.

answers.value: Engaging in a therapeutic relationship with the woman
Repeat the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale to monitor symptoms

questions.question: Psychoeducation includes:
questions.description: Psychoeducation involves discussing healthy positive lifestyle choices, giving information on the client’s mental health condition, and informing about treatment options.

answers.value: Information on the client’s mental health condition

keyLearningPoints.description: What are not symptoms of bipolar disorder?

questions.question: What are not symptoms of bipolar disorder?
questions.description: Experiencing hallucinations and delusional thinking, being disorganised, socially anxious, and behaving with a lack of insight and abnormally are not common symptoms of bipolar disorder. They are common symptoms of schizophrenia.

answers.value: Experiencing highly elevated moods with an agitated state of mind
Experiencing very low moods, negative feelings of despair, with an inability to engage in or enjoy daily activities.
Sometimes experiencing hallucinations and delusional thinking and behaving with a lack of insight and abnormally.
Trick question, the answer is all three.

keyLearningPoints.description: Anxiety disorders are a group of related conditions that include:

questions.question: Anxiety disorders are a group of related conditions that include:
questions.description: Generalised anxiety disorder, panic disorder, compulsive obsessive disorder and post-traumatic stress disorder are all types of anxiety disorders.

keyLearningPoints.description: Symptoms of puerperal psychosis include the rapid onset of:

questions.question: Symptoms of puerperal psychosis include the rapid onset of:
questions.description: Difficulty sleeping and setting, unable to think rationally or be reasoned with, hallucinations, and dramatic, erratic and untypical behaviour are all symptoms of puerperal psychosis.

answers.value: Inability to think rationally or be reasoned with

keyLearningPoints.description: Infants of mothers who suffer from depression have higher rates of:

questions.question: Infants of mothers who suffer from depression have higher rates of:
questions.description: Infants of mothers with depression have higher rates of low-birth weight, hospital admissions, incomplete immunisation schedules and stunting.

keyLearningPoints.description: What should you do if you experience negative personal consequences of caring for women with perinatal mental health conditions?

questions.question: What should you do if you experience negative personal consequences of caring for women with perinatal mental health conditions?
questions.description: Practicing self-care and seeking professional support or counselling are some of the ways you can manage the negative personal consequences of caring for women with perinatal mental health conditions.

answers.value: Kindly tell the woman that you can no longer care for her
Ignore it and carry on as normal, it will probably pass

keyLearningPoints.description: People with schizophrenia are more likely to:

questions.question: People with schizophrenia are more likely to:
questions.description: People with schizophrenia are more likely to abuse substances, living in sub-optimal housing and experience social isolation.

keyLearningPoints.description: Symptoms of general anxiety disorder include:

questions.question: Symptoms of general anxiety disorder include:
questions.description: Persistent excessive worrying and repetitive negative thoughts that can overwhelm and debilitate and distract the woman, creating feelings of stress and fear are all symptoms of general anxiety disorder.

answers.value: Persistent excessive worrying and repetitive negative thoughts that can create feelings of stress and fear
Extreme fear that results in sudden and recurrent panic attacks
Repetitive, unwelcome thoughts and illogical, extreme urges to perform specific actions (compulsions)
Distressing and persistent reactions following a traumatic event

questions.question: People with anxiety often experience:
questions.description: Anxiety often feels like stress, fear, worry, or a lack of ability to control thoughts.

answers.value: Stress, fear, worry, lack of ability to control thoughts
Lack of impulse control, occasionally euphoric, hearing voices, lack of desire to sleep of eat.
Negative feelings of hopelessness and an inability to enjoy daily activities

keyLearningPoints.description: Why may women not want to disclose a history of mental health conditions?

questions.question: Why may women not want to disclose a history of mental health conditions?
questions.description: Women may not disclose a history of mental health conditions due to shame, guilt, embarrassment, a fear of judgement, a fear of stigmatisation, or a fear of their baby being taken away.

answers.value: Fear of judgement of them as a mother
Fear that their baby will be taken away

keyLearningPoints.description: Why would you suspect that the woman has depression and not the baby blues?

questions.question: Why would you suspect that the woman has depression and not the baby blues?
questions.description: Compared to the baby blues, perinatal depression tends to persist for more than a few days, and often worsens over time.

answers.value: Symptoms persist for more than several days
No personal or family history of mental health conditions
Symptoms occur within the first 2 weeks after delivery

questions.question: Talking therapy/empathetic counselling includes:
questions.description: Talking therapies or empathetic counselling includes using reflection, active listening and motivational interviewing.

answers.value: Increasing the woman’s knowledge and understanding of her perinatal mental health condition and options for treatment
Motivational interviewing, where you encourage the woman to talk about her need and desire for change
Explaining signs, symptoms, risks, and potential side effects of medication

keyLearningPoints.description: Which of the following are guiding principles for clinicians to adapt their practice into trauma-informed care?

questions.question: Which of the following are guiding principles for clinicians to adapt their practice into trauma-informed care?
questions.description: The six guiding principles of trauma-informed care are: safety, collaboration, trust, empowerment, choice and respect for diversity.

keyLearningPoints.description: What percentage of the population suffer from schizophrenia?

questions.question: What percentage of the population suffer from schizophrenia?
questions.description: 1-2% of the populations suffer from schizophrenia.

questions.question: Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) aims to:
questions.description:
Cognitive behavioural therapy aims to: 

 

Teach skills to deal with intrusive negative thoughts, rebuild self-esteem and self-identity, and improve acute symptoms by assisting to reframe the disturbing thought patterns.

answers.value: Teach skills to deal with intrusive negative thoughts
Help women to ignore past trauma
Improve acute symptoms by assisting to reframe the disturbing thought patterns

keyLearningPoints.description: Put these three action principles of psychological first aid in the correct order:

questions.question: Put these three action principles of psychological first aid in the correct order:
questions.description:
The 3 steps of psychological first aid are: 

 

1) Look: Check that the woman is safe 

2) Listen: Ask about the woman’s concerns and listen calmly 

3) Link: Help the woman address her basic needs by accessing services for her

answers.value: Look: Check that the woman is safe
Listen: Ask about the woman’s concerns and listen calmly
Link: Help the woman address her basic needs by accessing services for her

keyLearningPoints.description: High levels of cortisol in the blood due to prolonged maternal anxiety can be damaging to the foetus’s:

questions.question: High levels of cortisol in the blood due to prolonged maternal anxiety can be damaging to the foetus’s:
questions.description: High levels of cortisol due to prolonged maternal anxiety can lead to the foetus having poor neurodevelopment and an increased likelihood of developing schizophrenic disorders later in life.

answers.value: Likelihood of developing schizophrenic disorders later in life

keyLearningPoints.description: Short-acting contraceptives can only be used over short periods of time. True or false

questions.description: Short-acting contraceptives can be used over short and longer periods of time.

questions.description: When used correctly and consistently, male and female condoms are the only contraceptives that can protect against sexually transmitted infections.

keyLearningPoints.description: The procedure technique of inserting an implant must be aseptic. True or false?

questions.question: The procedure technique of inserting an implant must be aseptic. True or false?
questions.description: The procedure of inserting an implant must be aseptic to prevent infection.

keyLearningPoints.description: If a woman needs a new implant after having one removed, where can the new implant be inserted?

questions.question: If a woman needs a new implant after having one removed, where can the new implant be inserted?
questions.description: If a woman needs a new implant after having one removed, it should not be inserted into the old incision site.

keyLearningPoints.description: After inserting the IUD/IUS, how long should you leave the strings?

questions.question: After inserting the IUD/IUS, how long should you leave the strings?
questions.description: Once you have inserted an IUD/IUS, cut the strings 3 cm from the cervix.

answers.value: The length of the woman’s vagina

keyLearningPoints.description: A woman with HIV can safely get an implant. True or false?

questions.question: A woman with HIV can safely get an implant. True or false?
questions.description: A woman with HIV can safely get an implant.

keyLearningPoints.description: When used consistently and correctly, male condom use prevents 80% to 95% of HIV transmission that would have occurred without condoms. True or false?

questions.question: When used consistently and correctly, male condom use prevents 80% to 95% of HIV transmission that would have occurred without condoms. True or false?
questions.description: When used consistently and correctly, male condom use prevents 80% to 95% of HIV transmission that would have occurred without condoms.

keyLearningPoints.description: Combined oral contraception contains artificial versions of which naturally occurring hormones?

questions.question: Combined oral contraception contains artificial versions of which naturally occurring hormones?
questions.description: Combined oral contraception contains artificial versions of progesterone and oestrogen.

keyLearningPoints.description: Which of the following are important before deciding on a contraceptive?

questions.question: Which of the following are important before deciding on a contraceptive?
questions.description:
Before deciding on a contraceptive, is it important: 

That the woman understands the side-effects, health benefits and risks 

That the woman knows how to use it effectively and safely 

That the woman has been offered a variety of methods so that she can give her preference

answers.value: That the woman understands the side-effects, health benefits and risks
That the woman knows how to use it effectively and safely
That she gets consent from her partner
That the woman has been offered a variety of methods so that she can give her preference

keyLearningPoints.description: What is important for providing successful counselling?

questions.question: What is important for providing successful counselling?
questions.description:
Successful counselling involves:  

Showing respect 

Letting the client’s wishes and needs guide the discussion. 

A private setting 

Checking the clients understanding

answers.value: Let the woman’s wishes and needs guide the discussion

keyLearningPoints.description: The woman should take one contraceptive pill at the same time every day for the most effective protection against pregnancy. True or false?

questions.question: The woman should take one contraceptive pill at the same time every day for the most effective protection against pregnancy. True or false?
questions.description: The women should take one contraceptive pill at the same time every day for the most effective protection against pregnancy.

keyLearningPoints.description: What type of checks needs to be done before inserting an intrauterine device (IUD/IUS)?

questions.question: What type of checks needs to be done before inserting an intrauterine device (IUD/IUS)?
questions.description:
Before inserting an IUD or IUS, you must: 

Perform bimanual examination 

Examine the cervix 

Ensure absence of pregnancy 

Ensure absence of sexually transmitted diseases

keyLearningPoints.description: Which methods are categorised as long-acting reversible contraceptives?

questions.question: Which methods are categorised as long-acting reversible contraceptives?
questions.description: Implants and intrauterine devices (IUD/IUS) are long-acting reversible contraceptives.

keyLearningPoints.description: When does a woman not qualify to get an IUD?

questions.question: When does a woman not qualify to get an IUD?
questions.description: A woman does not qualify for an IUD if she is pregnant or if she has gonorrhoea or chlamydia.

answers.value: If she has gonorrhoea or chlamydia
Immediately after surgical or medical abortion
She is within 48 hours after delivery

keyLearningPoints.description: When can a women get an implant?

questions.description: A woman can get an implant at any time in her menstrual cycle.

answers.value: Only if the woman has not been pregnant
Only in the first 7 days of her menstrual cycle
Any time in her menstrual cycle
Only if the women have been pregnant before

keyLearningPoints.description: Side effects of copper intrauterine device

questions.question: What side effects can women expect after getting a copper intrauterine device?
questions.description: Side effects of a copper IUD include changes in bleeding patterns, especially within the first 3-6 months (typically more irregular, longer and heavier bleeding, with more painful cramps).

keyLearningPoints.description: What should you recommend the woman to look out for following IUD/IUS insertion?

questions.question: What should you recommend the woman to look out for following IUD/IUS insertion?
questions.description:
Following IUD/IUS insertion, you should recommend the woman to look out for the following: 

Bleeding changes   

Symptoms of pregnancy

Misplacement of the device

Fever

keyLearningPoints.description: When the women come back for routine follow-up after inserting IUD, it is always required to perform a pelvic examination. True or false?

questions.question: When the women come back for routine follow-up after inserting IUD, it is always required to perform a pelvic examination. True or false?
questions.description: When the women come back for routine follow-up after inserting IUD, it is not required to perform a pelvic examination.

keyLearningPoints.description: What should you do if a woman requests for her IUD to be removed?

questions.question: What should you do if a woman requests for her IUD to be removed?
questions.description: If a woman requests the removal of her IUD, you should do so as soon as possible.

answers.value: Tell her to come back when she is having menstrual bleeding

questions.question: When is it recommended to have a follow-up contact after intrauterine device (IUD/IUS) insertion?

Following IUD/IUS insertion, a follow-up contact is recommended either: 

After the first menstrual bleeding, or 

3-6 weeks after insertion

keyLearningPoints.description: Which surgical procedures can be used to perform tubal ligation?

questions.description: Mini laparotomies or laparoscopies are commonly used to perform tubal ligations.

questions.question: What is important for you to ask the woman in order to help her choose the right contraception for her?
questions.description: Asking about the client’s fertility intentions, preferences and past experiences are important to ask in order to help them choose the right contraception for them.

questions.description: Local anaesthetic injection should be administered as pain relief prior to inserting a contraceptive implant.

keyLearningPoints.description: Which of the following side effects are normally seen with copper IUD, but not with the hormonal IUD (IUS)?

questions.description: Prolonged and heavy monthly bleeding, with more cramps and pain are side effect more commonly seen with the copper IUD, but not with the hormonal IUD (IUS).

Nausea 

Mood changes 

Headaches

questions.description: The most long-lasting contraceptive method in this case is the copper IUD.

keyLearningPoints.description: How does the vaginal ring prevent pregnancy?

questions.question: How does the vaginal ring prevent pregnancy?
questions.description: The vaginal ring works by releasing hormones that are absorbed by the blood stream and prevent ovulation.

answers.value: It damages the sperm cells before they can enter though the cervix and meet the egg cell
The hormones are absorbed into the bloodstream and prevents ovulation
It thickens the cervical mucus, preventing sperm and the egg from meeting

keyLearningPoints.description: Which of the following contraceptive methods do not have any delay in fertility after stopping/removing it

questions.question: Which of the following contraceptive methods do not have any delay in fertility after stopping/removing it
questions.description: Fertility after stopping/removing an IUD, a combined patch, or a vaginal ring returns without delay

questions.description: A vasectomy is fully effective after 3 months of the procedure.

keyLearningPoints.description: Place these steps of the non-touch technique while inserting an IUD in the correct order

questions.question: Place these steps of the non-touch technique while inserting an IUD in the correct order
questions.description:
The correct order of the non-touch technique while inserting an IUD is: 

Load the IUD into the inserter while the IUD is still in the sterile package, to avoid direct contact 

Cleaning the cervix thoroughly with antiseptic before insertion 

Being careful not to touch the vaginal wall or speculum blades with the uterine sound or loaded inserter 

Passing the uterine sound and loaded inserter only once each through the cervical canal

Cleaning the cervix thoroughly with antiseptic before insertion
Being careful not to touch the vaginal wall or speculum blades with the uterine sound or loaded inserter
Passing the uterine sound and loaded inserter only once each through the cervical canal

keyLearningPoints.description: Which side effect of the contraceptive implant is the most common?

questions.description: The most common side effect of the contraceptive implant is changes in bleeding pattern.

keyLearningPoints.description: How does the copper-IUD prevent pregnancy?

questions.question: How does the copper-IUD prevent pregnancy?

By preventing a fertilised egg from attaching to the uterine wall

Get the woman’s verbal consent

Allow her to empty the bladder

Look for scars

Ask her to lie down in left lateral position

keyLearningPoints.description: What is the drug of choice for the intermittent preventive treatment of malaria in endemic areas?

keyLearningPoints.description: How can you identify multiple pregnancy by abdominal examination?

questions.description:
SFH is more than expected. 

3 or more foetal poles palpable.

keyLearningPoints.description: Identify the statements that are true in relation to preventive anthelmintic treatment during pregnancy.

questions.description:
Preventive anthelmintic treatment during pregnancy is recommended where anemia is a severe public health problem. 

A single dose of albendazole or mebendazole is given after the first trimester.

Recommended where anemia is a severe public health problem

keyLearningPoints.description: A pregnant woman comes for her first ANC contact. She has not been immunized with Tetanus Toxoid before. How many doses should be given during pregnancy and at what interval?

questions.question: A pregnant woman comes for her first ANC contact. She has not been immunized with Tetanus Toxoid before. How many doses should be given during pregnancy and at what interval?
questions.description: You should give 2 doses in one month interval.

keyLearningPoints.description: What is the dose of iron and folic acid supplement recommended during the antenatal period?

The recommended dose of iron and folic acid supplement during the antenatal period is: 

30 mg to 60 mg of elemental iron and 400 mcg (0.4 mg) of folic acid

30 mg to 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg (0.5 mg) of folic acid
30 mg to 60 mg of elemental iron and 400 mcg (0.4 mg) of folic acid
50 mg to 80 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg (0.5 mg) of folic acid

questions.description:

keyLearningPoints.description: What is the risk that may occur if the foetus is cephalic and the head is not engaged?

questions.description: If the foetus is cephalic and the head is not engaged, there is a risk of cord prolapse.

keyLearningPoints.description: How many postnatal care visits are recommended?

keyLearningPoints.description: When is the woman in the postnatal period?

questions.question: When is the woman in the postnatal period?

keyLearningPoints.description: Which statements are true regarding partner involvement in postnatal care?

Partner involvement can increase access and use of relevant health services for the newborn.

Blood pressure and pulse

keyLearningPoints.description: The postnatal woman contacts you because she experiences bleeding after birth. When should you advise her to go to the hospital?

questions.question: The postnatal woman contacts you because she experiences bleeding after birth. When should you advise her to go to the hospital?

answers.value: The amount of bleeding is increasing rather than decreasing
The blood is turning brown in colour
The lochia starts to be foul-smelling

questions.description: Guidance on breastfeeding, dietary advice and advice on exercises and postpartum contraceptives are part of the initial postnatal care counselling.

answers.value: Dietary advice and advice on exercises
Counsel on solid foods for the newborn

keyLearningPoints.description: For how long should the postnatal woman be recommended to take iron in anaemia risk settings?

You should make sure to:

Measure her blood pressure

Make sure to offer immediate referral if she has elevated blood pressure (>140/90)
Ask if she has experienced other symptoms of pre-eclampsia

All mothers at risk should be offered pre-exposure prophylactic and antiretroviral HIV-treatment.

questions.question: Upon discharge, when should you tell the mother to react and contact you?

The mother should react and contact you if:

She experiences persistent pain in the perineum or draining pus 

She has fever and feels ill 

She experiences breast complications

If she has fever and feels ill
If she experiences pain on urination

Breastfeeding counselling should be provided to all mothers, starting from the antenatal period.  

The newborn should be kept warm and not be separated from the mother after birth.

The newborn should be kept warm and not be separated from the mother after birth.
Breastfeeding does not need to be initiated within the first 24 hours so the mother and newborn can rest
Breastfeeding should be initiated within the first hour after birth

keyLearningPoints.description: What is true about yellowing of the skin (jaundice) in the newborn?

questions.description:
Yellowing of the skin within the first 24 hours is not normal and you should react to this. 

Yellowing of the palms and soles at any point of time during the postnatal period is not normal and you should react to this.

Screening for hyperbilirubinemia before discharge is important to identify the newborns in need of treatment.

answers.value: Yellowing of the skin within the first 24 hours is not normal and you should react to this.
Yellowing of the palms and soles at any point of time during the postnatal period is not normal and you should react to this.
Yellowing of the skin will always resolve itself and does not need to be treated
Screening for hyperbilirubinemia before discharge is important to identify the newborns in need of treatment.

keyLearningPoints.description: What is the normal body temperature for a newborn?

questions.question: What is the normal body temperature for a newborn?
questions.description: The normal body temperature for a newborn is between 36.5-37.5°C

questions.description:
To prevent mastitis, you should advice the woman to do the following:

Instruct on good hygiene to keep breasts clean

Recommend breast massage and hand expression of milk  

Support and check the newborn’s breastfeeding technique incl. right position and attachment 

Suggest the use of warm or cold compresses according to the wish of the woman

answers.value: Instruct on good hygiene to keep breasts clean
Recommend breast massage and hand expression of milk
Support and check the newborn’s breastfeeding technique incl. right position and attachment
Suggest the use of warm or cold compresses according to the wish of the woman

keyLearningPoints.description: Which statement about breastfeeding is false?

questions.question: Which statement about breastfeeding is false?
questions.description: The newborn should feed at least 8 times on demand in 24 hours including day and night.

answers.value: Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for the first 6 months of life
Breastmilk contains many important nutrients and antibodies for protection of the newborn
The newborn should feed maximum 8 times per day
Complementary foods can be given from 6 months, while continuing to breastfeed up to 2 years.

keyLearningPoints.description: What can be the cause of sore and cracked nipples?

questions.question: What can be the cause of sore and cracked nipples?

answers.value: Excessive swelling of the perineum or vulva

keyLearningPoints.description: What is true about postpartum blues?

questions.question: What is true about postpartum blues?
questions.description:
Postpartum blues often occurs within the first couple of days after birth and it is a normal condition.

It is important to listen to and encourage the woman and give emotional support during her postpartum blues. 

If the postpartum blues symptoms last for more than 2 weeks, you should screen for postpartum depression and refer the woman if necessary.

answers.value: Postpartum blues often occurs within the first couple of days after birth and it is a normal condition
It is important to listen to and encourage the woman and give emotional support during her postpartum blues
It is not recommended to involve the family or partner in supporting the woman throughout the postpartum blues
If the postpartum blues symptoms last for more than 2 weeks, you should screen for postpartum depression and refer the woman if necessary

keyLearningPoints.description: How would you treat anaemia postpartum?

questions.question: How would you treat anaemia postpartum?
questions.description: To treat anaemia postpartum, you give 60 mg iron twice daily for 3 months.

answers.value: Give 20 mg iron twice daily for 3 months
Give 60 mg iron twice a week for 3 months
Give 60 mg iron twice daily for 3 months
Give 600 mg iron once daily for 3 months

keyLearningPoints.description: What is important to ask and know when counselling the woman on postpartum contraceptives?

questions.description: Copper IUD, female sterilization, and condoms are all contraceptive methods that can be used immediately postpartum if the woman is breastfeeding.

keyLearningPoints.description: What are the signs of an effective attachment when breastfeeding?

Signs of effective attachment are: 

The newborn’s lower lip is turned outwards

The newborn only sucks on the nipple and not the areola.

keyLearningPoints.description: What is the correct order for how to treat an eye infection in the newborn?

questions.question: What is the correct order for how to treat an eye infection in the newborn?
questions.description:
The correct order for how to treat an eye infection in the newborn is: 

1.	Wash hands with clean water and soap 
2.	Gently wash the eye with a wet, clean cloth with boiled and cooled water
3.	Apply 1% tetracycline eye ointment 3 times a day

answers.value: Wash hands with clean water and soap
Gently wash the eye with a wet, clean cloth with boiled and cooled water
Apply 1% tetracycline eye ointment 3 times a day

keyLearningPoints.description: What is true about HIV infection and breastfeeding?

questions.description:
The following about HIV infection and breastfeeding is true:

The risk of infection is significantly reduced when the mother receives ART.

The risk of infection is significantly reduced when the mother receives ART
Mastitis and sore/cracked nipples can increase the risk of infection for the newborn
If the mother is on anti-retroviral therapy (ART) she is not allowed to breastfeed

keyLearningPoints.description: What should you advice and support the woman to do within the first 24 hours after birth?

questions.question: What should you advice and support the woman to do within the first 24 hours after birth?

answers.value: Go home as soon as possible
Stay in the health facility, rest, eat and drink
Initiate breastfeeding and bonding with the newborn
Give the newborn to a healthcare professional so she can get a proper sleep

questions.description:
You should ask the postpartum woman the following during the routine PNC assessment: 

Have you had any pain, fever, or bleeding since delivery?

How are you feeling?

Have you decided on any contraception?

Have you decided on any contraception?
Do you have any problems passing urine?

questions.question: What is false about safe sleep for the newborn?
questions.description:
The following about safe sleep for the newborn is false: 

The newborn should sleep on the side

The use of a bed net is only needed when sleeping at nighttime

The newborn should sleep alone, not near the mother.

answers.value: The newborn should sleep on the side
The use of a bed net is only needed when sleeping at nighttime
The newborn should sleep on the back (supine position)

keyLearningPoints.description: When should the mother alert you regarding the newborn within the first 24 hours of birth?

questions.question: When should the mother alert you regarding the newborn within the first 24 hours of birth?
questions.description:
The mother should alert you if: 

She observes breathing difficulties such as chest in-drawings

questions.question: When should urine output be checked and documented?

answers.value: Within the first 2 hours after birth
Within the first 6 hours after birth

questions.question: When should pregnant women in rural areas attend the maternal child health clinics?
questions.description: All women must be seen whenever a Maternal Child Health Clinic takes place, irrespective of their gestational age

answers.value: Only if they experience any danger signs when the clinic is there
All women must be seen whenever a MCH clinic takes place
All women must be seen Irrespective of their gestational age

questions.question: How can Misoprostol be administrated?
questions.description: Misoprostol should be administrated sublingually for PPH treatment.

certificates.content:
Certificate Exam

Welcome to the Safe Delivery Champion Certification Exam! This exam will assess your practical knowledge of BEmONC Signal Functions, Newborn Management, and Infection Prevention. The correct options can be found in the content provided throughout the Safe Delivery App.

Please be aware that closing the Certification Exam or the Safe Delivery App will cause the test to shut down and start over. Allow yourself between 1-2 hours uninterrupted to complete the exam.

Before we begin, please read the following instructions carefully:

This exam is based on clinical scenarios. After each of the 15 cases, you will be asked a series of questions. Please answer the questions by choosing from the listed options. Keep in mind there may be more than one correct answer.

At a health facility, clinical situations handled incorrectly may be harmful, critically harmful, or deadly for a patient. The scoring of this exam will also reflect this.

  • If you provide a harmful answer, half of the total score for the specific question will be deducted.
  • If you provide a critically harmful answer, the entire score for the specific question will be deducted.
  • Providing a deadly answer will cause you to fail the certification.

If you fail the Certification Exam, don't worry! You can continue to use the Safe Delivery App to update your knowledge and retake the exam in 14 days.

Once you have passed the exam with more than 70%, you can proudly call yourself Safe Delivery Champion for an entire year and claim your certificate (sent to you by email).

Now it is time to begin the Certification Exam. Good luck!

cases.description: You are delivering a primigravida at term with spontaneous onset of labour and normal progress of first and second stage. There is clear liquid. The newborn is delivered and screams immediately.

questions.question: 1.1. What can be done to reduce the risk of post-partum haemorrhage (PPH)?

answers.value: There is no effective way to prevent PPH.
Active management of the third stage of labour more than halves the risk of PPH.
Performing episiotomy might reduce the risk of PPH moderately.
The effect of giving uterotonic drugs right after delivery to prevent excessive bleeding is scientifically documented.
Only when excessive bleeding occurs something should be done.

questions.question: 1.2. What will you do after the delivery of the newborn to prevent PPH?

answers.value: If available, I will give an oxytocin (10IU) injection within one minute of birth – otherwise I’ll give Misoprostol (3 tablets) orally  or 0.5 mg Ergometrine IM, if blood pressure is normal or 0.5 mg Ergometrine IM, if blood pressure is normal.
I will deliver the placenta by squeezing the top of the uterus.
I will allow the placenta to deliver physiologically or deliver the placenta by gentle, controlled cord traction.
To deliver the placenta I will have to pull the cord with force.
I will keep the newborn away from the mother for one hour to focus my attention on the uterus.

cases.description: A 23-year old woman has just given birth to twins. Both newborns are doing fine. The placenta has been delivered and examined, and no tissue seems to be missing. There are no visible tears to the perineum. Suddenly, the woman starts to bleed heavily.

questions.question: 2.3. What are the FIRST steps you will take now?

answers.value: Call for help and perform rapid assessment and emergency management.
Give uterotonic drugs and perform bimanual compression if the bleeding is not controlled quickly.

questions.question: 2.4. You have performed the initial steps to manage the bleeding, and you are now performing a bimanual compression. An assistant is still present with you in the delivery room. What do you ask the assistant to do?

answers.value: Position the head down if not done already.
Measure haemoglobin level if not done already.
Encourage the mother to drink as much as she can.
Insert two IV lines and give up to 3 litres of IV fluids running as fast as possible.
Give drugs to help the uterus contract.
Get the mother up and walking.

questions.question: 2.5. Your assistant asks about the dosage and administration of fluids and uterotonic drugs. What are the correct drugs and their correct administration and dosages? Select the ones you find appropriate:

answers.value: 1-2 litres or more of normal Saline fast or Hartmann's solution - one bag at a time!
10 international units of Oxytocin IM if not already administered.
Oxytocin drip: 20 international units in 1 L Normal Saline or Ringer’s lactate 1 drop each 10 seconds.
30 international units of Oxytocin IV push.

Oxytocin drip: 20 international units in 1 L Normal Saline or Ringer’s lactate: Infuse as fast as possible.Continue at 20 IU in 1 L at 20 drops/minute in second bag. Do not give more than 3 L of IV fluid with oxytocin.

cases.description: Fifteen minutes ago, an 18-year old woman gave birth to a boy after an uncomplicated delivery; the placenta was delivered five minutes later and appeared intact. Shortly after, you noticed an ongoing bleeding and administered relevant uterotonic drugs. You have just performed uterus massage, and the uterus is clearly well-contracted. However, the bleeding persists.

questions.question: 3.6. What are the possible causes of this bleeding?

answers.value: A tear in the cervix and/ or a perineal tear.
Placental tissue remaining in the uterus.

cases.description: A 27-year old woman gave birth 20 minutes ago. You have tried to deliver the placenta three times by controlled cord traction without success. The mother has started to breastfeed the newborn, when you suddenly discover an uncontrolled, heavy bleeding from the vagina. The mother also starts to feel dizzy and cold, and sweat appears on her forehead.

questions.question: 4.7. Which initial actions do you perform?

answers.value: Give antibiotics and perform uterus massage.
Prepare intravenous accesses and give uterotonic drugs.

cases.description: A 20-year-old woman, pregnant for the first time, presents in week 34 at your health facility.

questions.question: 5.8. At all antenatal care visits it is important to:
5.9. If the woman’s blood pressure is 165/90 mmHg, you must:

answers.value: Give IV hydralazine and Magnesium Sulphate.
Give her paracetamol, send her home and recommend drinking plenty of fluids.
Assess blood pressure again after only 10 minutes in a reclined position.
Ask for signs of severe preeclampsia.

questions.question: 5.10. Signs of severe preeclampsia are:

answers.value: Systolic blood pressure at or above 160 mmHg.
Diastolic blood pressure above 90 mmHg and swelling of feet..
Right upper quadrant abdominal pain and visual disturbances.
Decreased urine production and persistent headache.
None of the above are signs of severe preeclampsia.

questions.question: 5.11. Which statements are true regarding severe preeclampsia:

answers.value: Usually cured spontaneously and management should be expedited.
Usually progresses and can become life-threatening.
In unstable cases, the newborn should ideally be delivered within 24-48 hours no matter gestational age.
Magnesium Sulphate must be given as fast as possible by IV push.
Systolic blood pressure at or above 160 mmHg is the most important parameter to control.
Delivery is the final treatment but the condition can worsen in the post-partum period.

questions.question: 5.12. If the woman has an initial seizure, you must:

answers.value: Call help and protect her from hurting herself.
Treat blood pressure at or above 160 mmHg systolic with IV antihypertensives.
Give Magnesium Sulphate 4 g IV as fast as possible (push).
Give Magnesium Sulphate 4 g IV very SLOWLY.

cases.description: A 25-year-old pregnant woman comes to you in the morning with intermittent lower abdominal pain. According to herself and her antenatal card, she is “at term” and has attended antenatal care twice in this pregnancy. HIV status is negative. She gave birth 3 years ago at home with no complications, and the child is still alive. She has had a small amount of bloody vaginal discharge. On examination, the uterus is relaxed and not tender in-between regular moderate contractions, three in ten minutes. Head is well engaged. Foetal heart rate is 115 bpm.

questions.question: 6.13. What will you do?

answers.value: Refer to a higher level health facility because of bleeding.
Refer to a higher level health facility because of low foetal heart rate.
Perform vaginal examination to know cervical dilatation.
Tell her not to drink and eat as she is in labour.
Insert two large bore IV accesses.

questions.question: 6.14. Vital signs are normal, cervical dilatation is 4 cm at 9AM. What to do now?

answers.value: She is in active phase of first stage of labour. She should be admitted, and the alert and action line should be plotted onto the partograph.
I will assess foetal heart rate each 30 minutes.
I will do next vaginal examination after 2 hours.
I will do next vaginal examination after 4 hours.

questions.question: 6.15. After four hours, cervix is 6 cm dilated, membranes still not ruptured, foetal heart rate between 115 and 140 bpm, contractions are strong, four in ten minutes. Head is 1/5 palpable above pubic bone. What will you do now?

answers.value: She has normal progress because action line is not crossed.
She has prolonged labour because cervical dilatation is to the right of the alert line.
I will do artificial rupture of membranes.
I will get her up and walking, and I will ask her to urinate.
I will refer because foetal heart rate is not normal.
I will set up an Oxytocin drip (20IU in 1000 ml of Normal Saline) to improve progress

questions.question: 6.16. You rupture the membranes, clear amniotic fluid, cephalic occiput anterior, and fetal heart rate right after is 130 bpm. What to do?

answers.value: I will do next vaginal examination after four hours.
I will do next vaginal examination after (1-)2 hours.
Assess foetal heart rate every 15 minutes.
Assess fetal heart rate every 30 minutes.
Keep her on strict bed rest.
Encourage her to stand and walk.

questions.question: 6.17. After two hours, cervix is fully dilated. Head on the pelvic floor. Fetal heart rate is 110 bpm. Strong contractions and an urge to push. What to do?

answers.value: I will refer because foetal heart rate is too low.
I will perform vacuum extraction because foetal heart rate is too low.
I will allow her to push after emptying her bladder.
I will assess foetal heart rate each 15 minutes.
I will assess fetal heart rate after every contraction and at least every five minutes.

questions.question: 6.18. After one hour of pushing, she has not delivered; foetal heart rate has been 80 bpm for five minutes. She is very tired and says she cannot continue pushing much longer. Amniotic fluid is clear. Contractions are strong; 4 in 10 minutes. What will you do now?

answers.value: Pushing for one hour is an indication of vacuum delivery.
Maternal exhaustion is an indication of vacuum delivery.
Foetal heart rate below 100 bpm for five minutes is an indication of vacuum delivery.
Vacuum delivery can be performed at any foetal presentation.
Vacuum delivery should be avoided at a gestational age of less than 36 weeks.
Vacuum delivery causes damage to the anal sphincter in less than 1 in 100 deliveries.

questions.question: 6.19. You perform vacuum delivery. Which of the following actions are right?

answers.value: Bladder must  be empty and abdominal palpation should be done
The cup must be placed just behind the anterior fontanel.
The cup should be placed just in front of the posterior fontanel.
You pull when there is no contraction and episiotomy is always indicated.
You stop the procedure if 30 minutes have passed from applying vacuum delivery
You should protect the perineum during delivery of the head.

cases.description: A 14-year-old girl comes to you with “lower abdominal pain for the past three days” and she is shivering. She looks ill, sweaty and tired. She walks slowly and talks with a whispering voice. Her mother says she might have malaria.

questions.question: 7.20. What will you do?

answers.value: I will give her oral malaria treatment and ask her to come back the next day.
I will ask her if she was pregnant and has had an illegal abortion.
I will measure her blood pressure, pulse, respiratory rate and temperature
I will ask when her last menstruation was, and I will do a urine pregnancy test.
I will talk to her alone without the mother and assure her that she has my confidentiality.
I will do a malaria test, give her oral malaria treatment and send her home.

questions.question: 7.21.Pulse is 120, BP 90/50, temperature 39˚ C, RR 24. Her pregnancy test is positive, and she admits to have had an illegal abortion. Her last menstrual period was 10 weeks ago, and she probably got pregnant two weeks later. What do you do?

answers.value: Call for help and assess vital signs each 15 minutes.
Give her oral antibiotics and admit her.
Give her IV antibiotics and wait 12-24 hours.
Insert two IV lines and a urine catheter and give her at least 2 litres of IV fluids fast.
Await results of malaria test, send her home and see her the next day.
Keep her on “nothing by mouth” (not allowed to eat or drink).

questions.question: 7.22. You admit her and give her 2 litres of normal saline in 30 minutes. Urine output is 50 ml., yellow and clear. BP 110/60, pulse is 110. TP is 39,5. What to do?

answers.value: I will give her IV antibiotics and wait 12-24 hours.
My tentative diagnosis is septic abortion. I will do a vaginal examination and an abdominal palpation.
I think this patient needs evacuation of the uterus as fast as possible.
I will teach her a lesson and send her home without treatment as she committed a crime.
There is a chance that the pregnancy can survive, so I will not do an evacuation until an ultrasound examination confirms that the foetus is not viable

questions.question: 7.23. She has pain only over the pubic bone – no rebound or indirect tenderness. Uterus is very tender when moved. Minor vaginal bleeding and foul smelling discharge. What do you think?

answers.value: A septic abortion is like an abscess and must be treated as such by surgical intervention such as manual vacuum aspiration.
These young girls are fooling around, if I care too much for her, others will follow her bad example. So I need to be hard on this wrong behaviour to prevent more of its kind.
In places where abortion on demand is legal, many more girls have sex before marriage, get pregnant and have abortions.
A septic abortion can cause death if not treated immediately.
Patients are always safe once intravenous antibiotics are started, so now I will await recovery for 12 to 24 hours.

questions.question: 7.24. You prepare her for evacuation of the uterus, but you have no sterile gloves. What will you do?

answers.value: I will only do the procedure with sterile gloves.
I can proceed and do the procedure because only the tip of the cannula needs to be sterile.
The uterus is already infected and this procedure is lifesaving, so I will proceed anyway.
If I clean my hands with soap for five minutes, I can use normal gloves.
I should disinfect my hands with alcohol or air dry after washing hands.

questions.question: 7.25. What is true regarding post abortion care?

answers.value: Manual vacuum aspiration has more side effects than dilatation and curettage.
Manual aspiration can be done safely up to 12 weeks of gestation.
After evacuation of the uterus in a patient with septic abortion, intravenous antibiotics should be continued for 48 hours after the woman is fever free.
Modern contraception is not a part of post abortion care it should not be mentioned for patients who had post abortion care.
Performing manual vacuum aspiration causes a high risk of infertility later in life and should therefore only be performed when antibiotic treatment for 12-24 hours has been unsuccessful.
A septic abortion causes a risk of infertility later in life.

cases.description: A pregnant woman comes to the hospital at 1 PM together with her husband because of spontaneous rupture of the membranes, which happened at home at 12 noon. Amniotic fluid is clear, blood stained mucus show, no contractions. She is 22 and is giving birth for the first time. Gestational age is around 40 weeks. She looks happy, healthy, and well-nourished. Fundal height is 40 cm., foetal movements are plenty. Foetal heart rate is 140 bpm. Presentation is cephalic, well engaged, only 1/5 is palpable above the pubic bone.

questions.question: 8.26.a. What will you do?

answers.value: I will do vaginal examination to assess cervical dilatation.
I will do vaginal examination to make sure there is no prolapse of the umbilical cord.
I will measure her vital signs.
If vital signs are normal, I will send her out walking and ask her to come back when there are contractions. If there are no contractions, she should come back the next morning.
It is likely that contractions will start spontaneously.
I will not do a vaginal examination as it is not necessary.

questions.question: 8.26.b. Labour pain starts at 5PM, regular contractions- 3/10 minutes. Normal vital signs, FHR, and uterus between contractions. Clear amniotic fluid. What will you do?

answers.value: I will send her out to walk, plan to assess foetal heart rate after two hours and perform a vaginal examination after four hours.
I will keep her on IV antibiotics and nothing by mouth (no drinking or eating).
I will check her antenatal card to see her HIV status, and if she had her tetanus vaccination.
I will insert a urine catheter and two large bore IV lines.
I will reassure her that everything is all fine and encourage her to let her husband or another relative accompany her during birth.

cases.description:
She is HIV negative and had her tetanus vaccination. She gives birth the next day at 1.30PM. She had a vacuum extraction performed because of prolonged second stage. A post-partum haemorrhage of 900 ml is controlled by uterus massage, oxytocin, and misoprostol. She has a perineal laceration that is repaired. The newborn is not breastfeeding well. 
Can you identify risk factors that could attract an infection for this woman?

questions.question: 8.26.c. Can you identify risk factors that could attract an infection for this woman?

answers.value: Giving birth for the first time

questions.question: 8.27. You send her home. The next day, she returns supported by her husband to avoid falling. She is not looking well; sweating, dizzy, and breathing fast. What to do?

answers.value: I will say that it is normal to be tired after childbirth and ask relatives to come to her home to cook and do the housework. Then send her home.

I will give her oral antibiotics, tell her to drink plenty and then send her home, instructed to stay together with her husband so that she is not alone. She should come back the next day if she is not feeling better.
I will assess her blood pressure and pulse.
I will assess her body temperature.
I will assess her respiratory rate.
She does not look good; I will find her a bed immediately.

questions.question: 8.28. Her TP is 35,5˚ C. Pulse 140 bpm. BP 80/40 mmHg. Respiratory rate 26/minute. Normal skin colour. Tender, well contracted uterus. Slight vaginal bleeding. What to do?

answers.value: Give broad spectrum IV antibiotics. If in a malaria area, add malaria treatment according to protocol.
If in a malaria area, she should have malaria treatment, other antibiotics should only be given if a malaria slide returns negative.
Make sure she has free airways and give oxygen, if available.
Call for help. She has septic shock and can die in your hands; you can’t manage it safely alone.
Insert two IV lines, give at least two litres crystalloids IV fast, insert urine catheter.
Send malaria slide and await result before treating with any antibiotics.

questions.question: 8.29.You stabilize her and give antibiotics. BP is 90/60 mmHg. Pulse 100. Respiratory rate 24/minute. TP 36,5˚C. What will you do next?

answers.value: Assess her mouth, ear, and neck.
Do chest auscultation and palpation of her breasts
Do abdominal palpation, vaginal examination and assess her perineal wound.
Assess her skin to see if she has a rash or erythema.
If her urine output is less than 50 ml per hour, more IV fluids must be given
Assess vital signs every hour until stable.

cases.description: You suspect puerperal sepsis(postpartum endometritis). You treat with IV antibiotics for 24 hours, but she is still not doing well. Blood pressure is 90/50mmHg, pulse 110bpm, urine output 600ml the last 24 hours, respiratory frequency 25 per minute. Her lower abdomen is tender, no rebound tenderness, there is foul smelling discharge.

questions.question: 8.30. What will you do?

answers.value: I will change antibiotics and wait another 1-2 days for recovery.
It is normal that recovery takes three days or even more. Patience is important.
I should suspect retained products of pregnancy and prepare her for a cautious manual vacuum aspiration.
I will consider referring her to a higher level health facility.

cases.description: You are delivering a woman in your health center. She is 21 years old and it is her first pregnancy. It is night  time, and you are alone on duty. The delivery is an uncomplicated vaginal delivery, and there is no thick meconium. There is little bleeding and you have administered intra muscular oxytocin to the woman. Immediately after the newborn is born, you place the baby on the woman’s abdomen.

questions.question: 9.31. What steps would you take now? Select as many as are appropriate:

answers.value: Suction the newborn’s mouth and nose.
Clamp and cut the umbilical cord.
Dry the newborn with a towel.
Wrap the newborn in a warm cloth.
Suction only if the newborn is born with thick meconium.
Check if the newborn is crying and breathing well.

questions.question: 9.32. During your assessment, you find that the newborn is not crying and it is floppy with no tone and has blue lips. What is your next action?

answers.value: Clamp and cut the umbilical cord.
Start ventilation breaths with a ventilation bag.
Stimulate the newborn by drying and rubbing its back with a dry cloth.
By one minute of age, the newborn should breathe on its own or otherwise be ventilated with a bag and mask.

cases.description: A 38-year-old woman presents to the labor ward in the evening with a history of contractions for the whole day. On vaginal examination, the cervix is fully dilated and there is no meconium staining of the liquor. On delivery, the newborn is pale and limp and making a few gasping respirations. Its hands and feet, as well as the tongue, are blue. The newborn is not responding to stimulation by drying and rubbing the back.

questions.question: 10.33. What are the four most important actions to take now?

answers.value: Open the airway, position the head in neutral position.
Place the mask over the mouth and nose and give five inflation breaths.
Continue with ventilation breaths if breathing is still not sufficient.

questions.question: 10.34. You now start ventilation breaths. What are important actions to provide successful ventilation breaths?

answers.value: Position the head in a 'sniffing' position.
Ventilation breaths shoud be given at a rate of 40 breaths per minute
Stop to assess the newborn after 15 ventilation breaths.
Make sure that the chest moves with every breath.
Stop ventilation after one minute no matter what the condition of the newborn is.
Assess the newborn every minute during ventilation breaths.

questions.question: 10.35. You have provided  ventilation breaths, and the airway is open. The child is not crying or breathing. It is blue and the heart rate is below 100. What to do?

answers.value: Continue resuscitation with 60 ventilation breaths per minute.
Continue resuscitation with 40 ventilation breaths per minute.
Counsel the mother on the loss of her newborn.
Make sure that the chest rises on every ventilation breath.

questions.question: 10.36. The chest is not rising during your attempts to provide ventilation breaths. What do you do?

answers.value: Try to lift the newborn’s jaw forward.
Make sure that the chest rises on every ventilation breath.

questions.question: 10.37. The newborn is now crying with a good color and tone. What will you do now?

answers.value: Place the newborn with its mother, skin-to-skin.

cases.description: A 25-year-old second gravida comes to the health facility after she passed plenty of clear amniotic fluid at home. There is no bleeding and no contractions. Her gestational age is 32 weeks according to her last menstrual period that she is certain about.

questions.question: 11.38. What will you do?

answers.value: Give the mother 12 mg Bethametasone IM 2 times with 24 hours apart or 6 mg Dexamethasone 4 times with 12 hours apart to prevent respiratory distress in the newborn.
Ask the mother to go home and return if she gets contractions.
Measure hemoglobin level if not done already.
Give one litre of IV fluids running one drip per second.
Gives the mother Ampicillin 2g IV every six hours to prevent severe infection in the newborn.

questions.question: 11.39. After 20 hours, the mother spontaneously delivers a newborn with normal Apgar score. The newborn weighs 2000 grams. Heart rate is 180 bpm. Respiratory rate above 60/minute. What to do?

answers.value: Give the newborn Ampicillin 50 mg per kg IV/IM twice daily for minimum two days.
Give the newborn Gentamicin 5 mg/kg IV/IM once daily for minimum two days
Keep the newborn warm by constant skin-to-skin contact with the mother.

cases.description: You are delivering a 21-year-old primigravida with spontaneous onset of labour. She was fully dilated after eight hours of active labour, and there was clear amniotic fluid at birth. There were no signs of foetal distress during delivery.

questions.question: 12.40. The newborn is delivered. After five minutes, the Apgar score is 10 and the newborn’s respiration is normal. What will you do now?

answers.value: Wrap the newborn in a cloth and put safely in an incubator.
Check breathing and colour every five minutes.
Give 1 mg of vitamin K, IM. and apply eye ointment.
Start breastfeeding within the first hour after birth.
Give the newborn to the mother, instruct in skin-to-skin contact and tell her to call if the condition changes.
Give the mother and her family privacy and continue with other duties.

questions.question: 12.41. The mother contacts you after 10 minutes because she has observed bleeding from the umbilical cord. What is the FIRST thing you do?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/cord_care_after_1_hour

answers.value: Examine the newborn and look for danger signs
Assess the umbilical cord immediately. If there is ongoing bleeding, compress the umbilical cord with your fingers and call for help to re-tie it.
Give antibiotics according to local guidelines.
Inform the mother that there is no rush; you will attend to her in 10 minutes.
Inform the mother to start breastfeeding.

cases.description: A primigravida is in labour. She is at term with no complications during pregnancy, the delivery has progressed normally and the foetal heart rate has been within normal range at auscultations. But at delivery, the newborn is covered in thick meconium and it does not scream or breathe.

questions.question: 13.42. You stimulate the newborn immediately followed by suction of the mouth and nose, and then the newborn starts crying, has Apgar 10 and is responsive. How do you examine and monitor the newborn afterwards?
13.43. All of the below are danger signs, which ones do you assess under Breathing?

answers.value: Respiratory rate below 30 per minute or above 60 per minute.
Pale, weak pulse, capillary refill time above three seconds.

cases.description: There were no danger signs, and after 12 hours you discharged the mother and newborn. After two days, the mother comes back with the newborn and tells you that it is not feeding well and sleeps a lot. On examination, you notice that the newborn has a free airway but is breathing very rapidly with cyanosis, chest in-drawings and a respiratory rate of more than 65.

questions.question: 13.44. How do you continue?

answers.value: You send the mother home and ask her to come back if the newborn still does not feed.
You assess other danger signs under Circulation, Disability and Exposure.
You suspect a severe infection and give antibiotics, Ampicillin and Gentamycin IV/IM.
You keep the newborn warm by skin-to-skin contact to the mother.
You increase feeding frequency to every second hour. If unable to suck, you give expressed milk 10ml/kg per cup or nasogastric tube.

questions.question: 13.45. The heart rate is 190 bpm and you observe a lethargic, pale newborn with a capillary refill time above three seconds. What do you do?

answers.value: You ask the mother to feed the newborn.
Immediately give the newborn phenobarbital 10 mg per kg.
Weigh the newborn so you can give the correct amount of fluid.
Estimate weight and give the newborn 10 ml of normal saline per kg IV.
You suspect a severe infection and give antibiotics.

questions.question: 13.46. Two days have passed and a nurse calls you because the newborn has been convulsing for more than three minutes. What will you do?

answers.value: You council the mother on her loss of the newborn.
Check blood sugar. If not possible you assume the newborn has low blood sugar.

cases.description: You are at work in your health facility on a Monday morning after a very busy weekend. There has not been running water in the tap for a long time, and you find that there is no more alcohol-based handrub.

questions.question: 14.47. What will you do?

answers.value: Contact the pharmacist to get some alcohol-based handrub.
Make your own alcohol-based handrub based on the WHO formulation with material purchased in your town.
Continue your work without handrub and without the possibility of washing your hands.
Get someone to collect water from the nearest water supply, so you have water in a bucket with a pitcher and soap.

cases.description: At your facility there are two women in delivery at the same time, and you are the only skilled birth attendant on duty, but you have two assistants to help. The first woman in labour is a primigravida at term with spontaneous onset of labour and normal progress of first stage. The second is a multigravida (3rd birth) at term also with spontaneous onset of labour and normal progress of first stage.

questions.question: 15.48. You have alcohol-based handrub and you can perform hand hygiene. What will you do?

answers.value: Put on sterile gloves without using the handrub.
Take off nail polish if wearing it and make sure fingernails are no longer than 3 mm.
Rub your hands in alcohol-based handrub.
Take off rings, watch, and bracelets.

questions.question: 15.49. Which dangerous sources that can spread infections are present in the labour ward?

answers.value: Using a wet and shared towel to dry hands after hand wash.
Using a large soiled piece of soap for hand wash, which has been lying in a soap disc filled with water.
Medical instruments such as scissors and resuscitation equipment.

questions.question: 15.50. You have now done a vaginal examination on the primigravida woman and her cervix is 7 cm open, and you are going to do vaginal examination on the multigravida woman. What will you do?

answers.value: No need to use alcohol-based handrub, as you were wearing gloves in the previous vaginal examination.
Inform the woman and put on sterile gloves correctly.
Use the same pair of sterile gloves for this woman as you did to the other.

questions.question: 15.51. With 15-minute intervals, both women gave birth to babies that immediately screamed. Both mothers are stable. You are now going to weigh the two newborns, and will need to weigh them right after each other. Which of the three orders do you follow?

answers.value: Weigh the first newborn, give it to the mother, weigh the second newborn and give it to the mother.

Use alcohol-based handrub, weigh the first newborn on a piece of cloth, give it to the mother, weigh the second newborn on a piece of cloth, give it to the mother, put antiseptic on the weight and dry it with a clean cloth and use alcohol-based handrub.

Use alcohol-based handrub, weigh the first newborn on a piece of cloth, give it to the mother, put antiseptic on the weight and dry it with a clean cloth, use alcohol-based handrub, weigh the second newborn on a piece of cloth, give it to the mother, put antiseptic on the weight and dry it with a clean cloth and use alcohol-based handrub.
